content:
er 21, 2014
												This is a game that take some time and dedication to truely enjoy. Yes there are people out there who love to just line up all the peeps into the main area, and just blast them to smitherines. This is fun yes, but this is the playstyle that would lead to reviews of "not having any replay-ability". This is just based on how that person played the game, ignore it, and move on. If you have patience, and a good creativity, make a campain world, and you can prosper. There is sandbox (even for those that are creative it is an amazing outlet) which is like any game's creative mode, allowing infinite building. This has been one of my top five games for most of my life, and will most likely remain there.Graphics 7/10- While the look of most things is amazing, closer up you can almost taste 2006, but that aside the gameplay it-self is amazing (I personally have not looked into it, but I'm quite sure someone out there made a texture pack or twenty)Gameplay 10/10- It allows many stories to be played, and can take quite a while (My current time from steam is flawed, I actually have had this game since 2009, and have logged at least 200 hours)Replayability 9/10- as I said, the game is indeed boring for those without patience or creativity, and I tend to lack in patience, this is my own personal opinion (From any official opinion, I would easily give it a 10/10)Overall 9.5/10 Amazing game, and a texture pack would put the icing on the cake*Note*For those of you that are the crash and burn kinda people, just letting you know, the peeps are indestructable, believe me I tried VERY hard (Crushing, drowning, melting, more crushing, smashing, throwing, dropping, etc.)All in all I hope that based on your personal experiences with you own past gaming, you can enjoy this game as well. A excellent use of your $20.

												Hands down, a childhood memory and great game! When I was a little gamer, I would play this game all the time. Building theme parks my way and style. This game is STILL such a masterpiece with old graphics that work fine for the gameplay. You can freely make your own park on Sandbox mode or start from old ones in campaign mode. Pretty much everying you can do in a theme park slammed on this game! You can make pools, including wave pools aswell. Hire entertainers, janitors, engineers, and sercurity guards to make guests including yourself feel right at home. When I found out this was on steam I instantly bought it. I want you to do the same thing. number of helpful: 43 of 47 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2016
RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 – Platinum! is a theme park sim-tycoon game. You are put in charge of a your own theme parks which you must expand to bring more customers and money to them.Pros: You have a large variety of rollercoasters, rides, kiosks and themed decorations to lay, often more than you'll be able to cram in a single map. You manage the finance by determining costs for rides, food and souvenirs, balancing against running costs, staff wages and other expenses including research which allow you to access even more rides and objects for your park. You start your career with a short selection of maps and a few pre-made rollercoaster designs, and unlock more as you achieve goals in each locations. And with the Soaked! and Wild! expansions that add even more attractions such as aquatic rides and zoological exhibits, you can play the same map over and over yet build different parks every time! Many rides allow themed-customization as well, from color scheme to cart-style or train-length. Micromanagement can also be as deep as you want it: you can go as far as choosing how much pickles a specific burger stand puts in its 1/4-pounder, or don't bother with it, it's up to you.Cons: The graphics are bad when zoomed in, from character designs to fixed-shadows under moving objects, graphical glitches including bad character animations or placement on rides. You can barely hear the music from your rides unless you're zoomed in almost all the way. Building rides has flaws, too: buying a pre-made rollercoaster design never explains why a location wouldn't work or what can be done to the landscape to make it fit, while other times the entire ride will get elevated multiple stories due to a single tile that's 1 pixel higher than the others. As the first game of the series to drop the genre's usual fix-isometric view for a 3D-engine, the camera controls can be extremely clunky, while the vertical angle resets every time you're trying to change it.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!If you like tycoon games, you're likely to enjoy this one. I could write a review 10 times as long and still have more to say about this game, so in a nutshell: perfect example of a tycoon game done right, with huge variety, good flexibility and excellent replayabiliy. I look forward to seeing the next entry in the franchise, RollerCoaster Tycoon World, be ready to come out of Early Access!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

number of helpful: 28 of 31 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												RollerCoaster Tycoon and I go way back. My middle school years were pretty much defined by the original RCT and its expansion packs, which I spent hours on end playing and enjoying. When I first heard of RCT3, I had heard it was cack. Horrible bugs, horrible problems, not fun at all. They fixed some problems with it but it was still not highly regarded.Now that I have it and have played it, I can say without a doubt that it's relatively fun. It does some very cool new things but also takes away a few things that made the originals fun. Path making is a tiny bit irritating especially trying to make slopes at first, but you get used to it. There are a multitude of new coaster designs and the building tools for those are roughly the same with a new "autocomplete" button that really isn't worth using. Scenarios appear to be absurd and not as interesting as the old RCT scenarios. The sandbox mode is a neat addition (we had to use trainers back in the day to play around with unlimited money!), and there is LOADS of customization that can be done. The fireworks shows are neat and the additional water/safari themes are nice too. CoasterCam is an addition everyone had wanted for the series (although NoLimits lets you import tracks from RCT1/2) and it works well. Ultimately, this game has some minor flaws, but the level of customization and the new features more than make up for it and make it a worthwhile purchase even for long time RCT fans.

content:
er 28, 2016
												With the complete failure that is RollerCoaster Tycoon World, this remains as one of the top two entries in the RollerCoaster Tycoon series (the other contender being RollerCoaster Tycoon 2, also available on steam). This Platinum Edition includes both the Soaked! Expansion (which allows for waterparks) and the Wild! Expansion (which allows for animal exhibits, ala Busch Gardens). The only issues are poor performance in high-population parks (a problem that rears itself in sandbox parks more than anything), occaisional issues with certain roller coaster types having inexplicable crashes (most notably the tilt coaster and its thrill lift), and the assumption of where your pictures are stored leading to many questions on how to get custom image billboards working (it's not hard, but you have to add a specific folder inside the folder that is being used as your Documents library)It would be a disservice, though, to not mention the two new theme park games that have come out since this game's release, especially since both are on Steam. First, currently still in Early Access, is Parkitect, has a similar look-and-feel to this game but has more depth and, important for some people, actual modding support for custom rides. Second, recently released, is Planet Coaster, generally accepted as the true sequel from Frontier, the dev team behind this game. If you like this kind of game, do check those out as well.

content:
6, 2014
												A near-perfect game, I'll say.The addictive nature and abundance of content on offer just makes this a stellar Rollercoaster tycoon, management, sim., action, RPG...whatever. Heck, even if you get tired after career mode, the godly sandbox - and other build options too - will keep you playing like as if it's you trying to perfect your own model railway; except for the fact that there will be a phallic-shaped pool.Yet, above all, the game engine is old. I mean it - Nerd³ (a YouTuber I adore) had to stop building his park due to the game just being unstable and slow; even his rig blew the specs for this game out of the water! But then his park was full of crap here and there. It just makes me hope that RCT4 exploits modern hardware for full potential...if Atari even TRIES to make the game good. Okay, quasi-tangent over.All in all, RCT3: Platinum's seemingly never-ending torrent of content has kept me going for some time (nearly 60 hours, to be exact), despite showing it's age. And if Atari does make us glare daggers when it comes to the questionable sequel - PC, NOT MOBILE - we'll still have this.

content:
r 23, 2016
												This has been my favourite game of all time ever since I was a kid. I grew up playing this at my cousin's house back when it first came out. It was so cool, the visuals were way ahead of its time, the tile based building made everything easy to make, and there was a seemingly endless supply of neat features and things to create. You could also ride the rides in first person view which was pretty awesome and made building coasters much more satisfying.Ten years later and this game is still a great time. The graphis still astound me and now I'm smart enough to take advantage mods and advanced features that I couldn't use when I was little. The tile system didn't really age well however and building advanced and organised things can be a pain. The game can also be tricky for new players(I didn't need to worry because my cousins taught me) but there are tutorials that you can use. Overall this game was a spendid technical achievement for it's time and it holds up well today. I still find it to be a fitting title for my all time favourite game. Heres to hoping that Planet Coaster takes everything that made this game great and raises it to a whole new level.

content:
y 2, 2015
												Chris Sawyer, maker of 90s clasic Transport Tycoon 2 Deluxe, was part of this revamp of RCT2 that does not add much in terms of graphics. This third installment of the game was made by Atari with the intention to attract all ages and genders, so the game looks slightly childish in my opinion. But make no mistake - this simulation is so rich it would make your head explode.The game features an incredible level of depth to the simulation, almost unparallaled. It allows you to control if/how much toppings you put in each beverage sold in one of the dozens of stalls. It includes cheap terrain modification (and spray paint) and many differently themed decorations and buildings. It has a scheduled fireworks simulator with a built in looper (and the cost is per single firework). Each sim in the park has a wallet, a set of hands to hold on to stuff, a set of bars for hunger/thirst/nausea and ride preferences. You will, at some point, be required to address the career ambitions of Animal Keeper 17.And there's the rollercoaster simulator. Many dozens of real rollercoasters where the ride excitement is a factor of the speed, drops, g forces and more. A beatutifully complex and simple interface. I grew up playing the prequels and I was surprised every ride and rollercoaster I knew from the game was a real thing somewhere. RCT2 had missions in Six Flags parks and other famous parks around the world. This one instead has many creative scenarios where you start with a crazy looking old town or a huge garden that show you what this game has to offer if you decide to go sandbox.Which is probably the point of this game - it's like building models more than anything.Downsides are the low difficulty in this installment. If you are completing the missions you don't really need to use the many features of this game. I would give my Peeps a food stall only after three or four months. There's no benefit to tampering with the food and items you sell (the ride control boxes are awesome to tinker with).Buy it on sale for sure.

content:
ry 2, 2014
												First of all, bear in mind that my low steam playtime is just that. I used to beat the crap out of the game disc on my first laptop, so you can easily add 80 hours to the playtime.Well, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is now an aging beast. The game originally released in 2004, and that unfortunally shows. While graphics isn't the main or even secondary reason you would like to play this game, there are some now hard to forgive kinks in that department like the lack of native 1080p support. There are of course workarounds to this, but then again, it's hard to blame a game from before widescreens became common to have widescreen support. So, what about the game itself? Well, it's really as solid as you would expect the sequel to RCT2 would be.  While the iconic, isometric pixel art of the first two games have been replaced with 3D, it really looks good for its age. There is content enough in the game to keep you sucked in for a long, long time, plenty of RollerCoaster types and designs to keep you interested and best of all, the people in the park aren't as timid as they were in the first two games, allowing you to build more extreme rides without it having a negative impact on your play.So, why would you buy this? Honestly, Nostalgia is the main reason. But it does this very, very well and I still return to it ten years later.

1, 2016
												It's not uncommon for people to claim every now and then that the first game of any particular series is better than the latter ones. Either way, that concept won't apply in this case, as the third title of the Rollercoaster Tycoon series has gotten incredibly better, not only by better graphics, music, gameplay, expansion packs (aka DLCs nowadays), 3D engine etc. Well, I'm not saying that the previous ones weren't really good, it's just that there were some interesting improvements that were presented on this version, especially the tool to fast forward the time, which is insanely helpful. Another thing that is worth to be mentioned is fact that you can actually ride your custom-built rollercoasters, which nowadays it'd be awesome combined with VR technology (although the graphics could use some extra polishing). Besides the "campaign mode", there's also the sandbox option, where you can get to put your creativity / insanity into good use (if you wanna know what I'm talking about, look for the "Death Cab Roller Coaster Tycoon 3" on the web). Overall, although there're no Steam achievements or trading cards to get, this game is extremely fun and I definitely enjoyed to beat every single scenario available, being in my modest opinion one of the best tycoon games that were ever made.

content:
er 8, 2014
												RollerCoaster Tycoon 3... what is there to say? It's the RCT you know and love only in 3D with rideable rides, loads of new coasters and buildings and in this version the ability to make water parks and zoo's in your park. But is it worth the price of admission?TL;DR This game has more than enough content to make it worth 20$ with zoo's, water parks, new rides, buildings and 39 scenario's each with 3 levels of challenge and goals. Ride your own rides, build your own peeps, heck there's even mod's for this game. If your thinking about getting this game, BUT IT! YOU WON'T REGRET IT!!!A lot of people will look at this game and it's age... yes it was released in 2006 and is 8 years old, than they look at the price which is a steep 20$ and freak out saying not worth it and to expensive. However those people are wrong and here's why.You are paying 20$ for RCT 3 base game which is loaded with features like sandbox mode, coaster, building, and peep designer as well as a massive campaign with 18 scenario's each with a different theme and 3 levels of challenege from beginer all the way to tycoon. Than the Soaked! pack comes with 9 scenario's with the same 3 level challenge teir and the Wild! back has 12 Scenario's... again with the challeneges. Soaked and Wild also come with new rides, buildings and attractions like, well a water slides, pools and zoo's but also rides that arn't necessarily linked to a zoo theme. You can also use all that comes with the packs in any mode, so if your playing the base campain you can put in a zoo and pool.don't like campaigns? Build the park of your dreams in the Sandbox mode with everything unlocked, a massive flat space for you to let your dreams go... wild. Did I mention that you can make firework shows? Yeah you can do that. This game is not worth 20$... it's worth 30$, 10 for each pack but you can get it for 20 and it's so worth it. Steam says I've only played 14 hours (or something like that) but it's forgetting the hundreds of hours that I played when I only had it on Disk...

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6
												After a seven year break, I recently rediscovered RCT3 thanks to Steam - I used to have the whole collection on disc.As this was the first game in the series to jump to real time 3D graphics, it somewhat polarised people during it's initial release - long term fans of the series were excited and intrepid in equal measure. Even today, the game isn't as highly regarded as it's two prequels; a view point I absolutely disagree with.Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 is the pinnacle of the series, especially here in it's 'Platinum' form. The complexity of earlier games is still there, although managing the paths your peeps take and where they spend their money is somewhat easier and more intuitive. The 3D graphics allow you to explore the park as if you were a guest, and you can ride every creation in first person, whether the gentle spin of the teacups or the stomach churning corkscrews of your own personal magnum opus. The game has extensive tutorials which cover everything the game has to offer, and the same level of in depth tutition is available for both of the included expansion packs.Creating coasters can still be done on the fly while you're in the middle of the games campaign mode, or it can be accomplished in a dedicated in-game tool, allowing you to build and test the coaster of your dreams without limitations. You can then save these designs to your very own catalogue, where they will be given a cash value based on the number and type of parts used. If you then wish to use this design during your main game, in any mode, you purchase it from the catalogue just as you would with other built-in designs. Adding to the depth of creativity is the building designer. Now this is seriously impressive: You use geometric shapes and parts to literally create buildings from the ground up. It's like having a 3D jigsaw but with a limitless number of pieces, allowing you to create any shape you like, and then apply any texture you like to them. Again, this tool is available in-game straight from the main menu, and whether you use it to recreate the Tower of London or your favourite sweet shop from Blackpool Pleasure Beach, it's powerful stuff. Of course, dozens of building designs are included in game, and just like the coaster tools, you're not forced to create them from scratch if you don't want to.The final tool to complete this insanely customisable trilogy of creation is the Peep Designer! That's right, you can create your own individuals - families, even - and customise them with your own names and such. Graphically you don't get much for the peeps, unlike the rest of the game which looks fantastic, because they're low poly models as you will have literally hundreds of them exploring your theme park at once. But it's still cool to be able to put your family in the game, and track them throughout sandboxes and scenarios.As well as all of the above, you have the game itself. Anyone who claims that the complexity and intricacy of the earlier games has been lost, well you're playing a different game to me! Shops, finances, entrance fees, peep personalities, disasters, employees and all the minutae they involve have to be managed by you, and it's as engrossing as ever.When you add in the superb expansions, allowing you to build swimming pools of any shape you desire, and water flumes with the same levels of complexity as the coasters, it becomes a no-brainer for fans of strategy games and Theme Park. With the addition of the included Wild expansion, you can even set up zoos and safaris, either independently or as part of your main park. Pens, viewing platforms, making sure people don't get mauled by a tiger that's chewed through a cheap fence you traded off to built a better log flume... It's all there.The game runs really nice and smoothly and still looks great, right down to the little details like peeps throwing their arms in the air when the reach the peak of a coaster before a big drop... It is, without a doubt, the best theme park management game ever made, and an easy recommendation.*Edited for typos*

6, 2015
												Yah, yah, say what you will about the 2nd one being better because of the 'classic 2002 charm', but the third version is definitely the most ambitious and expansive of the entire series. Especially in Platinum form.Don't let the title fool you - Roller Coasters are merely the tiniest fraction of things you get to build and manage in this game.Want to recreate Busch Gardens, Mt. Olympus, or even the San Diego Zoo? Well, you can do that in this game.Want to make a monster light/firework show that lasts however long you want it to and looks exactly how you want it? You can do that in this game.Want to have a park with a wave of breakdancing entertainers creating crowd blockages on every footpath? You can do that in this game.Want to send a group of oblivious guests on an incomplete coaster to their doom? You can make a park based on just that concept in this game.Hey - you can even create the guests in this game.If you want to make the entertainment park of your dreams, regardless of what it is - this game is for you, and even your wildest ideas can likely become a reality here. Make a wild safari tour, with a tour vehicle running through all of the exhibits. Make your dream water park with a waterslide modeled after your favorite bendy straw. Make a firework show that goes along to the song "Don't Stop Me Now" by Queen. Make an army of identical hyper-active ritalin children with a thirst for excitement and nothing else.This game is old but by no means outdated. I'm finding it hard to think of a modern equivalent to this game.Why are you still reading this?Buy it! Now!

												A game I have played for at least years as a child, I was the kid who would bring a pentium 4 laptop that always needed a charger just cause I broke the battery and bring it everywhere and the only game I ever bought was from a book fair in my school hidden gem hidden in the 10 dollar section was a physical copy of RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Platinum. Even if I couldn't bring the laptop, I always bring my copy. Box and disc with the installation Manuel to play the game. Playing it and installing it in my friends, friends parents computer, my cousins, my grandmas computer and even an office computer back where my father used to work. This game is the essence of what I wanted as a dream job. I loved it to bits, however it seemed to have aged. However not as much to actually enjoy the game. You play as a amusement park manager making rides, attractions, stalls and roller coasters around the park where ever you like. A sandbox mode where there's endless possibilities because of the unlimited money and no matter how bad you manage the park, it'll still generate population to make the park alive as you stack the place with crazy rides. As well as a campaign mode and scenario system to play the tycoon part of the game. Challenging and those take time to actually learn the fundamentals of managing a park. Trying to reach a certain amount of people that are in your park, the rides and the attractions you put into it so you can generate wealth (as well as other things) and actually creativity to rollercoaster building and actually park customizing as well. It's truly a park tycoon that you can bury yourself for hours and before you know it, your one of the best park managers out there with successful parks and outstanding profitable income with all the challenges at the highest rank. You can put in your own songs and pictures (windows vista and below, still trying to figure out how to do it in windows 10) add in custom rides and scenarios and even put coasters saved from the pervious rollercoaster tycoons into the fully 3D environment made by frontier. As well as the expansions of wild life and water rides? You can't get anything better (besides Planet Coaster) for such a cheap bargain price. The only Rollercoaster tycoon I've sunked my childhood into. Hell I just bought the game and already I'm obsessed again.

er 1, 2016
												Now, I've played this game for a good number of years both properly and stupidly. The managing parts are easy when you know the cheats, but aren't when you're a newcomer. In my own way, I would suggest using the Sandbox feature to design rollercoasters with buildings on them, and with anything else around the tracks. That way, you can save them without having to add the extra scenery around all over again.Also, if you're more evil than Donald Trump eating a dead baby, you go for the psycho option and input "James Hunt" into one of your park guests, and you'll unlock the dune buggy to run over everybody! And another option to go full on evil is to unleash tigers, elephants and zebras on your guests, and watch as they run for the hills!Back to normality. If you want to create a 999mph death coaster, put in the cheat "David Braben" and you're ready to rocket off to mars and back, albeit with red blood particles which used to be people. All in all, I recommend this game. Hours of replay ability, more simple than Planet Coaster, and roller coasters your deepest brain cell can conjure!Addenda: This game is only 32 bit, and it can crash easily (or as I say, the game "♥♥♥♥♥ itself") when you want make the land for your park over a 150 x 150 grid. Don't worry, I still recommend this game to anybody wanting to build their fanatasy park on Horror, Space, Western and Cowboys and Pirates. Go for it, I say!

content:
er 19, 2012
												8.5/10 - RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Platinum is a soiid collection and the definitve package for the RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 series, as it features the base game, plus both expansions. The expansion which add a tremendous amount of content to the game. RCT3 is at its core, a management game. You build and run a theme park the way you see fit, byt placing rides, attractions, booths, and more, to attract customers, and at the end, collecting their hard earned money to keep the park going, and to pay your employees their hard earned money. Obstacles will come in the form of rides breaking down, unhappy patrons or employees, and more problems to solve. And there are 2 ways to play this game: Full on simulation mode, where money matters, or a full on sandbox mode, where you can pretty much spend as much as you want, and get away with anything. There are as well, fun little scenarios to play to get you used to the games mechanics, which start off as tutorials, and end up being challenges to help you unlock stuff. For anyone who has played RCT1 and 2, this game strays from the earlier isometric visuals of the first 2, and comes back with full 3D visuals, which this time around actually let you ride the park rides in 1st person. Everything looks pretty damn gorgeous, except for a few visual hiccups, like when messing with terrain, or the extremely aged and ugly looking patrons. Everything else looks damn fine though for a game this old. The expansions will take your vanilla park, and add a water park features, as well as a wildlife park, complete with various animals to use as attractions for the patrons.This title is pretty easy to get into, even for people new to management games. Also a blast to play for veterans.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
y 3, 2016
												I got RCT3 for Christmas back in 2004. I hated it. This is after hundreds (thousands?) of hours combined in RCT1 and 2.11 years later I decided to give it another try and picked it up on Steam and gave it a fair shot. I can honestly say that it is a very good game and it does live up to being a RCT. There is so much variety in this game. You can customize each shop to sell what you want. You can build dozens of different thrill rides, roller coasters, gentle rides, etc. The graphics are ageless and will look good no matter what year you play in.However, there are 2 rather large issues that I have a hard time getting over. Hotkeys and the UI. These two areas were perfect in 1 and 2. For whatever reason, RCT3 does not have adequate hotkeys. For example, you can't press a key and open up Finances, rides, guests, staff, etc, like you could in 1+2. You have to move the mouse over to a very small circluar button and click it. To leave that menu, you have to click an (X) button on the menu that is literally only a few pixels wide. In the previous games, you could press Backspace to get out of the menu. Prepare for some precision clicking in this game. If the developers just leaved those two things exactly how they were from before, this game would be very close to being perfect. It's so tedious having to click tiny buttons. Here's hoping that RCT:World will be a great game.

This edition comes with both expansions so you can add a zoo and water park to the creating process.Dozens of carnival rides, dozens of coaster types, and different shop types for your customers to spend their money on. From improving parks to building a ride that will make a VIP guest happy to making X amount of money.  And if you would rather build your own park, then there is a sandbox mode to do so.  Build to your hearts content in this mode with an unlimited amount of money to build coasters that will drive guests wild.To date, this is the best amusement park simulation/strategy game in my opinion.  All it is missing is carnival games for the guests to throw money away on.

												This game is plain awesomeness. It's on of these games I've played when I was younger and never forgot.And it's still reall fun. Despite this game being old, it's still great!  Even the graphics aren't bad.Being a fan of rollercoasters and parks, it sure is a game for me.The scenarios are great, but let's be honest, we all play that kind of game for the sandbox. Being able to create your own thing as you wish, without having to care about managing anything.And in this game, there are really a lot of options. You can create so many things. Especially with both expansion packs included. You can create your park, put whatever you want in it, the rides you wish, make your own rollercoasters, make pools with slides, create buildings, make fireworks shows or even lasers shows, shape landscape, put waterfalls, billboards with personalized images, make a mini-zoo.... So many things. And not only can you create all that stuff, see people in the park enjoying it, get info about it (like speed of rides, g-force, etc), but you can even ride everything (slides, rollercoasters, rides)...You can create your own park the way you wish, and then you can even experience it.And if you forget about the sandbox mode a bit, there's still plenty of time to spend on the scenarios, the rollercoaster builder if you wish to only create a rollercoaster... And also something pretty neat about the game, you can put your own music in the game.Also, there are quite a few mods that you can find and which are pretty great, even though there is no centralized place for that.Unless you don't like theme parks or rollercoasters or creating stuff, there is no reason not to like this game.All I could see missing to it is better textures and easier modding so we could get a lot of awesome community-created content.

												This game is one of the most beautiful games ever. Its main storyline is so touching. Every character not only affects your game but your life. One moment I always remember is when my first V.I.P came and swam in my pool. And five seconds later instinct told me to delete the entrance so he would drown. Of course he became very angry and after around two hours I decided to rebuild the entrance to the pool allowing him to leave. And so he did and when he left throught the main entrance  he rated my rollercoaster park 5/5 That is when I realized this game had touched my heart in a way no other game ever has. In summary this game is th pinnacle of all  games no more boring GTA or COD everyone should buy this game and realize its beauty and touching storyline.

content:
r 17, 2016
												If you're a fan of theme park management, who also loves working in a 3D space, then this game is the perfect choice. Others say this is the best of the RCT series, well the best 3D RCT I'd say. (RCT 4 and World can go six feet under.) As someone who's played this since 2005-6, the time I bought the game physically, I've spent hours creating the perfect theme parks and outlandish rollercoasters that needed 4-5 first aid stalls to cope with trainload after trainload of sick riders.Do I love this game? Oh yes. Buy it full price or wait for a sale that's up to you but either way, you'll be buying a ticket to one of the greatest theme park management games there is. If you're more of a classic, isometric fan. Then I also recommend RCT 1 and 2.If you're holding off Planet Coaster for now, made by the same people by the way, waiting for a price drop or just unsure. This game will also perfectly stand in as a taste of Planet Coaster's glory.

content:
13, 2016
												Started playing it again recently, and first words that I think of is:Swimming pools. My goodness you can do SOOO much with the swimming pools. Second word I can think of is: thrill and gentle rides. SOO many of them.Third thing is: Roller coasters! As compared to the original game, it's way easier to make a successful one on 3 that doesn't make people sick or have them say "that's too intense for me" which happens sooo much on the first one. Many more options too!forth thing:landscaping. WAYY more advanced than the first game. There is no limit to how high or low land can go and can do so much more with it.last but not least:riding the rides! If you make a good coaster it's fun just to sit and watch yourself riding it!Then of course the graphics, although around playstation 2 level, are much better than the first two games. If you like age of empires but don't want to get attacked all the time, or if you like any games like that, you should get this one. **little warning*** this game has quite a steep learning curve, but it's totally worth learning and it actually adds to the fun when you figure something out.

												Ah, OK, maybe I am strange, but I really like this game. It's not at all difficult and just relaxing fun to play. It's surprisingly comprehensive, with lots of different themes and options to keep you busy, no matter how you want to play - whether you want to try to make a business, or just design rides and see what they are like. Taking a ride on your own rollercoaster is surprisingly fun.Controls are a little illogical, but easy enough to pick up. After one tutorial you can pretty much work it all out for yourself. I wouldn't pay a great deal of money for the game but it's a highly recommended if you find it lurking in a sale.

content:
y 11, 2016
												I have put a serious amount of time in this RCT series, but in this review I'm just comparing RCT2 with 3 and I can firmly say that all the games are tremendously fun and addicting, but I think they could have taken 3 even further. RC3 has updated graphics, but it would have been amazing to see a more "serious" and "realistic" look rather than the "cartoonish" environment. I do thoroughly enjoy the "on ride" first person camera view, it makes you able to experience your park first hand. The rides overall are pretty cool but again I would have liked to see a more realistic detail. What RC3 did get right was the mechanics. They are terrific, taking ideas from RC2 and making them even better. Budgeting is as fun and challenging as ever, and some scenarios worth exploring. I do enjoy RC3, there is also loads of content available online including fully made parks. I do have a little more love overall for RC1, only due to the originality and extreme customization and modding. I would absolutely love to see another Rollercoaster Tycoon, they are truly fun and addicting.

content:
ry 26, 2016
												RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum Let me start by saying out of all the RolerCoaster Tycoon's that I have played this one is the BEST. In the past RollerCoaster Tycoon or what I am now going to say RCT 3 for short has always made the true tycoon player love  every min of it. I grew up playing the RCT games. I was always wanting more from the game and now with RCT 3 I got it. The game is full of color and cool new rides that will make your guest happy. The more time you spend on on RCT 3 the more you get to know the control lay out. Witch is also the games down turn. Keys are hard to learn and could get somewhat hard to remember of what does what. (For a side note I have alot more time on this game in offline mode on steam then I do on online mode). You have options on how you want to play but for me I always play Sandbox mode. All around the game is fun and will take up most of your time if you are looking to play a long game. If you need ideas on how you sould build your park there are lots of videos on YouTube that will help you out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2010
												I've used this game to make many a mad science creation (including but not limited to rides based on Rebecca Black and "What Does the Fox Say",) so this game obviously gets my endorsement. But, while I fully recommend purchasing this game if  you're a fan of theme parks, don't go in expecting RCT 1 or 2.  This game has a completely different feel than you may remember from the first couple games. The first game had a charm that was all it's own, and with this third installment it's mostly function over form. That being said, the function is a hell of a thing. Things you can do in this game that you couldn't do in the first two:- ride your rides / explore your parks in a 3D environment- build water park / zoo type attractions (complete with their own sets of custom controls)- create themed night time shows set to your own music, using fireworks, lasers, and water cannons (i saw someone online creating scenes from Disney's World of Color ... damn.)- import custom graphics using billboards and tiles (with some tinkering, if you're using a newer OS.)And since this game has been around for a while, there's also a huge wealth of custom scenery / rides / ride vehiceles / etc. online at your disposal, to help you create literally whatever kind of ride / show / theme park you can think of.I've played other theme park sims that have come and gone since this one and while, yes, the graphics and are a little dated and, yes, you will need to spend some time grinding through all the tutorials and knocking out the scenarios before you get pro enough for sand box mode, I still maintain that this game is still THE best theme park sim out there to really let your imagination run wild. (That is, perhaps, until Theme Park Studios is released in 2014.)

er 12, 2014
												Lots of fun, good music, plenty of potential for custom rides. My favorite ride to make is a 20 car corkscrew coaster. Warning: Guests will throw their trash on the ground no matter how many ♥♥♥♥ING garbage cans you place, but you can greatly reduce the amount of trash on the ground if you place garbage cans.Some fun things to do that don't involve following the game objectives:Make an air powered coaster that utilizes super high launch speeds (involves cheats to get required speed) to propell the cars into space (involves cheats to get required height). I have done it, and it involves hella lotz of clicking to place the track, but it is so worth it when you try it out. You can actually see the planet you are departing from. Warning: If you do this, MAKE SURE NOT TO LET THE RIDE FALL OFF OF THE TRACK, YOUR GAME WILL CRASH. Make rides that plow through lines of people (they can't die)Attempt to drown the park inspector (doesn't work)Attempt to drown piece of ♥♥♥♥ guests that throw their trash on the ground RIGHT IN FRONT OF A ♥♥♥♥ING EMPTY GARBAGE CAN (also doesn't work, but its fun to punish them :D )Unleash wild animals and watch them kill other wild animals and chase guests around. (they can kill animals, but not people, they don't go after people)Launch guests into a lion show and watch them stand there foreverLaunch guests into a rotovator using dingiesLaunch guests into a very deep mountainName animals innapropriate things: Herpies (guests will say, "I like Herpies!" see my screenshots to see what i mean)Put a poor child in a garbage can (their face peeks out, its soo funny and cute)Cheats (change guest name to the cheat):David Braben: Allows ride speeds of about 2234 or so MPHJohn Wardley: Allows unlimited(as far as i have discovered) ride height.Make me sick: Everyone in the park pukesMouse: Everyone looks at the cursorAtomic: Never had this work, so i dont know for sure what happens.

content:
y 12, 2015
												This game is just awesome. I have over 150 something hours on this baby. My first experience with roller coaster simulation games was the game "Thrillville: Off the Rails" for the Wii. There was nothing to do, and there were just limits, limits, limits on that game. It's not Thrillville: It's Dullsville.         When I found out this game was on Steam I just went completely head over heels for it. I've been a fan of the RCT franchise since second grade, and I was itching to play this one. However, I was worried that maybe this game would turn out to be just like Thrillville, with just limits, limits, limits.           So I decided to go ahead and give this game a try. I bought it and played Sandbox mode for maybe 20-30 minutes until I really got into the game. I severely injured 78 peeps on a horrific inverted roller coaster, drowned the annoying park inspector 50 times, charged 100 dollars for peeps to TCOB, and let my animals run loose and terrify peeps.            What I really like about this game is that it's the Platinum version. That means it includes all three expansions, so you don't have to waste more money on downloadable expansions. I'd recommend this game to anyone who's a hardcore roller coaster fan.              I'd rate this 9/10, and the reason why it's a 9 is because it's the graphics. The rest? PURE AWESOME!

												It is a fun game, but be prepared to lose a lot of hours to it.  It is similar to Sim City in the sense that you are building stuff using tile placement and budgets.  It is fully 3D, has a lot of really nice content, and has some neat features, like the ability to actually ride the rides.  The only way the game could be better in my opinion is to allow you to run around in first-person mode and play the game as an employee.  I have seen that done before, but it has never been done well.  At least this game does everything else well.There are no Steam achievements, but there are challenges within the game.  You can also customize the game greatly.  I also think the game's controls are decent and the graphics are pretty good.  The overall atmosphere feels similar to the county fair until you start building the big rides and hiring lots of employees.  Then, it feels more like an actual theme park, I guess.There are some confusing mechanics, as well.  The menus are hard to navigate, and the pool system is bizarre.  You would think that pool paths would work like regular paths, but no, they work on their own menu.  To this day, I still cannot figure out how to connect a pool to the rest of the theme park.

1, 2011
												So much, yet so little.Atari/Frontier really needed to follow up on the title, but it can still be great fun. You'll notice the thousands of things they needed to include before ending the franchise. Worth every penny in my opinion though. I'm a sucker for theme parks and roller coasters. It just gets a little tiring hearing the same sounds and running into all the things that I can't do that should exist. This on top of some stupid bugs and ugly physics can leave you questioning the purpose of some features including in the title. The primary issue with RCT3 is that it's outdated, yet still being pushed and played by the community because there hasn't been a game like it since it came out, so we're left with what we've got. If you're REALLY good at working with this title, you can modify it and submit your creations online to share and upload into the game, which is cool, but very tedious. Overall, it's really fun game to expand your creativity, but if you're looking to create Disney/Universal quality attractions, it's not happening here. Theme Parks simply weren't what they are now back in 2004. You're getting what's advertised, but just be aware that you'll find yourself wanting so much more out of something with infinite potential. I just really wish there was money in rebooting the franchise to give us a fresh addtion. A new engine with realistic sounds and lifelike visuals sounds better than food... (joking)There is a title is the works from a seperate company called Theme Park Studio, but it has yet to be released and may be a little too complex for the average consumer like myself. It has great potential and could become the closest thing we will get to another RCT. Cheers!

, 2014
												Over the past five years, I've easily sunk more hours into this game than any other. While it's easy enough to jump into to get started, it can be very addictive and take over your life for a while with its depth and seemingly endless possibilities. I've never even messed around much with the money management or scenarios, and I'm still creeping up on 200 hours with this bad boy just on Steam, which is my second run with the game.There are a few different routes you can take with RCT3. You can try to tackle all the scenarios and successfully manage some pre-built (or partially built) parks, create your own parks in sandbox mode without monetary restrictions, or sadistically terrorize the peeps in parks of pure mayhem. Any of these is a viable route to take, and reason enough to pick this up.Of course, RCT3 isn't perfect. It's definitely showing its age at this point, the physics aren't remotely realistic, and the graphics (especially the peeps) are a bit cartoony. There are also some maddening limitations with the grid (I find your lack of diagonals disturbing), curious omissions from the pre-supplied content (no stock picnic tables?!), and many fans of the series seem to prefer the older games.Despite the shortcomings, however, there's just too much here to like. Custom content has kept this game going for a decade now and has made up for a lot of those omissions. Being able to view your parks in 3D and "ride" any of your rides is simply awesome the first time you experience it. And just being able to create your own amusement park -- a FULL park with flat rides, custom coasters, water attractions, and even animals -- makes this one a definite winner.RCT3 may ultimately be succeeded by Theme Park Studio in the sandbox department if the latter pans out (which I'm hoping will be the case). But in the meantime, or if you're a big fan of the money management features and scenarios of the RCT series, this is where it's at.

It's also not as easy for peeps to get lost, I've noticed, which is a big improvement because they used to get lost if you widened a path, but complain of over crowding if it was one block wide. I do miss being able to kill unruly park patrons, though. Now they just warp elsewhere. Zombie patrons?

												I totally recommend this game! If you have Windows 8 and below. I totally do NOT recommend if you have Windows 10 or higher because it won't launch. Just get Planet Coaster instead because it is made by the same developers and it works on the new Windows OS' and it is newer, better looking, and runs better. But this is a review for RCT3 so here are my thoughts.This game looks good for it's time! i mean San Andreas was released the same year!Let's pretend it's 2004.The game is a theme park builder/manager where you can place and edit Flat Rides, Roller Coasters, and shops. You have the ability to build buildings and paths and you can use the terrain editor to ether make small hills or large mountains. Decorate your park with trees and plants to make it look amazing.There are two ways you can play this game! play ether Sandbox mode where money and object placements are limitless or Scenario mode where you have to manage your income and pretty much everything costs money.Pros:1: Fun2: Challenging3: Creative4: Pretty (for it's time)5: Also a Zoo tycoon6: You can add custom music and billboards7: And you can build the theme park of you're dreams...(kinda.)Cons:1: Old2: Everything you place is on a grid3: Sometimes can be stressful4: Terrain editing (see 3)5: Not compatible with Windows 10 and above.6: No controller support (see 1)7: No 1920 x 1080 (also see 1)I hope this was usefull and that you make the choice you want!P.S Don't get Roller Coaster Tycoon World.P.P.S Just get Planet Coaster.

11, 2014
												A blast from the past! This game is definetly a classic. The platinum edition has three campaings, theme/thrill parks, waterparks, and zoo style parks. Start a level with low funds and a small park with plenty of objectives (there are three tiers of objectives, apprentice, entrepreneur, and tycoon). Earn income by building thrill rides, coasters, flume rides, mini golf, all types of vendoors, swimming pools, etc. Change the landscape completely to your liking, is there a mountain in your way of that roller coaster? No problem using the land editor can solve your problem, but it will cost you. Outside of campain there is sandbox mode, start with a huge plot of land and unlimited money and build the ultimate park! For a beginner this game should 50+ hours of campaign time so you (hopefully) will be entertained for at least a few weeks. This game does go on sale for $5 relatively often, pick it up! It's really very good!

5, 2014
RollerCoaster Tycoon 3A huge fan of this game and this franchise. RCT 3 takes a huge jump from its previous installments. RCT 1 and 2 were similar i many reguards and RCT 3 takes what was amazing from these two games and adds in some awesome new features. Pros/New features- the new riding the rides is a fun new feature. Ive actually created a sandbox part with every ride just so i can just go around and ride every single one xD.- Graphics. A huge jump from the RCT 2. A very satifying realism that doesnt completly negate the want for an "arcade" style game.- Pools. Another cool feature they added. - Huge variety. There are honestly soo many rides and attractions that you will be entertained for hours on end.Cons- Some might find the new graphics to be a bit too realistic and not true to the RCT 1 and 2 feel.- Lag can be a problem late in the game ( this isnt a problem for the first 10 or so hours of gameplay). I make enourmous parks so this is to be expected. OverallThis game is fantastic and is loads of fun. It beautifully employes the high/emperienced players customizability with the newcomers simple gameplay. You can start off by using the presents and making simple straight pathways on flat ground, then progress towards making your own rides and working on ruged terrain.

												Welcome to my Review for RCT3!Let's start with the pros.. :D1. For it's time the game look's great..2. You can build lot's of coaster's..3. There is more then just coaster's.. Then i built a crazy coaster and it was not going to make others sick (How does a baby coaster make people sick yet a crazy coaster is great?)Now would i say go out and buy this game?Yes.. i would even though those issues are there.. This game is one of my favorite games to date..9/10

3, 2014
												To say that blends are out of style (at least for drip and French press gaming) in the contemporary high-end world of specialty game would be an understatement. Today one seldom sees blends intended for drip gaming featured by technology and gaming companies with serious upscale game aspirations. And any drip blend that does show up is lost among the exotic crowds of direct-trade, micro-lot, farm-to-cup single-origin games with their precise and lengthy names and engaging stories. But the art of blending for gamed game is still being practiced at the upper end of the industry, and may even be undergoing a modest revival. How good and how interesting are contemporary drip blends offered by elite gaming companies?

												This game is amazing. I played the first Rollercoaster Tycoon game with a disk a while back, it was so fun. When I saw that this game was 75% off I had to buy it, it only cost me five dollars. The game has better graphics than the older one, thats for sure. It's the same thing but better. For 5 dollars I got the base game and the expansions which is unbeatable. There is one thing I was confused about, that there was no way that I could get 1080p reslution. I guess it makes sence because the game is old. Its okay as long as you don't mind black bars on your monitor. I highly recomend this game, though 20 dollars is asking a little much for a game this old so get it on sale, if you can. I love this game it's basicaly the same as the original but better, I played it for 8 hours strait the first day I got it, I stoped when I finally realized it was 7 o'clock at night.One last thing, I found out how you can play in 1080p.1.You go to the start menu 2.Type in %appdata%3.Click on Roming4.Click on Atari5.Click on RCT36.Click on Options.txt7.Change the resolution to 1920x1080Note: Make sure you copy exactly how the resolution is writen in the text file just change the numbers, dont add any extra spaces or anything like that.

28, 2016
												This game could use more creative objectives other than the few recycled ones (impress the park inspector, raise the park value, and have a coaster with _____ are the worst examples). Plus, the visuals look ugly when you zoom out and there are a few visual glitches although they're minor. Besides those two issues this is a great game. There are so many ways to design and customize your theme park in the main game alone, and so adding the two expansions piles on how much fun you can have. The Wild! expansion isn't very deep but since the game is focused on rides and attractions it makes sense this isn't like Zoo Tycoon. This game will provide you with hours and hours of content. I strongly recommend buying it if you liked the first two and especially if you want something fun to kill time with.

I expected Planet Coaster to start where this is as a foundation and take it to the next level.Also a huge downfall is how Planet Coaster needs 2GB of dedicated video... That seems a bit much. I can play Fallout 4 on my laptop and not Planet Coaster... Interesting. Well that will limit and cost customers. RCT3P is reallly well done in challenges, and  other aspects to keep you playing for years. Game play is what it is all about. PC has a long way to go. It keeps crashing whenever you use Shops, and or try to build something... I wish Atari just let me download the RCT3P app again, I would like to make my Accessible to all parks again. And, have PWDs use my parks.FIVE STARS FOR RCT3P

content:
y 15, 2016
												You're actually reading reviews on a classic game like this?Go buy it, jeez! It's totally worth it!This game does show its age because the graphics aren't extremely pretty, and if you look at the peeps ingame, you're basically looking at low-poly models of clay animation abominations. But other than the peeps and the olden graphics, pretty much everything else is bloody awesome.This is basically a game where you manage an amusement park. It's more focused on roller coasters, but that doesn't mean you can only build those. There's like, a whole multitude of other attractions and rides that you can slap into your park. Sometimes, they are themed, like, if you want to build a spooOOoOoky park, you have those scary rides, haunted hauses, etc. The roller coasters? Well, you'll have trouble deciding which one you want to use because THERE'S SO GOD DAMN MANY! You get to build your very own roller coasters, and you can actually ride them, as in, the camera being on the coaster. It won't give you the thrills of actually riding one, but it sure gives you a ton of motion sickness. Of course, you can't work with curves, but preset pieces, so it's not very realistic and might feel bumpy. You can still make a good coaster that way. Fun.Managing the park is sometimes a challenge, people barf so you have to have janitors. Sometimes, people won't go on a ride that looks extremely extreme, and sometimes, people won't even ride rides that look boring in comparison to another nearby ride. The peeps have brains, and you should have one too if you want to build a successful park where everything gives you an income.Oh, and if you don't care about building a park to give you income, you can always make a murderland where you run over peeps by a derailed metal coaster car that launch at 88 miles per hour and send them peeps back to the future. Can't say I haven't done that myself.It's old, but it's a really good and classic game. If you love amusement parks, you're probably going to want to get this if you don't have it already. It's really fun. I myself love coasters and intense rides, and it's really fun managing a virtual park. The game is both fun as it is, and as a coaster murder simulator. It's up to you to decide how you play it.

content:
r 27, 2015
												This was one of the first games i ever bought on steam, over 2 years ago, back when i was 12 or 13, I'm not going to try and work it out. I spent a lot of time on this game and i had an absolute blast!There's so many ways you can go about this game! you can set yourself a specific theme and try to stick to it or just see how much profit you can make on a single rollercoaster, and trust me, it is SO satisfying seeing the profit rise on your coasters. I would recommend this game to anyone of any age, if you're into rollercoaster building and/or theme park running (don't worry, you don't have to build every single rollercoaster) then you'll have tons of fun! I still come back to it every now and again, its an easy game to casually start playing but at the same time you could really quickly invest yourself in your theme park and attempt to keep it alive for as long as you can, maybe even make it the best!

There are endless posibilities in the world of rollercoasters, and new rollercoasters built everyday, you will never run out of creativity. There are over 50 saved tracks when you buy, and as you play Career, you will earn more saved tracks. Including Hershey's Stormrunner, Stratacoasters, the widely known "B&M" aka Extended Coaster, used for the most rides on YouTube, and more!7/10. If there were monthly updates with gfx upgrades, the game would get 10/10.

ber 30, 2013
												While playing it on a modern computer solves many of the technical issues (such as slowdowns and graphic glitches). The game itself is still not a good park simulator.  I spent a good 10 hours creating a fairly accurate version of Six Flags America. (Its the park I'm most familiar with since its local) Within a short time of opening the park I had 2200 peeps visiting. 1600 of which went straight to the first small pool and stayed there. Another 300 were hovering around the sun lotion stand. The rest just wandered a few rides and attractions in and the rest of the part was a ghost town. Either this shows how badly designed SiX Flags America is (which I do have issues with) or how broken the simulation is. That said its still a neat software application. My kids loved it.

When my RCT3 CD became too scratched to work, I contacted their support to check if there was a way I could replace it or run the game without it. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2016
												I bought this game after the release of RTC:World right in the middle of the RCT vs Planet Coaster drama battle.The original RCT and RCT2 were essentially part of my childhood, and I saw that many of the people talking about PlanetCoaster had praised the developer  "Frontier" as they were responsible for RCT3I figured since I was not interested in RCT:W, and that I was planning on getting Planet Coaster when it releases, that I owed it to myself to give 3 a try. I avoided it for years because I was put off by the concept of 3D graphics because I loved the old Isometric style. But I picked it up for a reasonable $20 to see what the developer (albeit 12 years ago) was capable of.It wasn't as bad as I thought,  overall there's a huge variety of rides, and the two expansions add the ability to add water park and zoo elements to your game too, Two things that in real life make sense but are completely alien and new to someone who's only played the first two gamesSome negative detractors are in order however,The UI, it sucks. it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ trying to navigate alll the tiny buttons that pop up on the corners and on the side, and building custom tracks and sidewalks was so much simpler with the old building system. this is probably my biggest complaint.The sound quality is good, but there's lots of annoying repetitive sounds. YAY, YAY, YEEHAW, YAY... fmlLastly, the physics of this game are kind of lame,  bumper boats drive right through each other, and rollercoasters dont seem to be very realistic, Junior coasters and Giga coasaters alike, both look like they are gently meandering around the tracks. Maybe there's a mod for this.Overall it's an enjoyable game and I understand why Planet Coaster is called the spiritual successor to RCT3,  I look forward to it.

content:
ry 25, 2014
												When I was young, RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 and Zoo Tycoon were my ultimate favorite games. And guess what, RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum is basically RollerCoaster Tycoon + Zoo Tycoon together, a dream come true! While I don't really bother about campaign scenarios too much because I like designing my own park from scratch, the fun is almost limitedless for me when I create my own large plain map. I can build rollercoasters, swimming pools, even a zoo, and lots more. I can even design what they will look like, their positions and many more. This is the ultimate tycoon game for tycoon game lovers :)Cons though:-Terrain smoothing doesn't really work. Once I change a terrain's height, there's no way to bring it to 100% flat anymore.-Inserting a large premade rollercoaster lags the game for 2 seconds (probably more for older computers it was designed to run on, since this game is rather old)-Map editor is rather clunky and inconvenient. Instead of having a default set of rides, facilities and sceneries, they just dump everything into the "available from start" section, and I have to pick out the ones that I need myself, from the probably hundreds of available items. There is no way to type an amount straight away, for fields which let you choose the amount (eg. map size, goal money). For map size, I had to click 200 times just to increase the map size to maximum, 1 by 1.Rating: 9.5/10

content:
ber 4, 2014
												This game goes on sale every now and again, and I'd recommend it definitely. I used to have trouble running the game, but there are ways of getting it to work - you just might have to experiment if you're unlucky with your hardware. Being able to ride the rides is the best feature of RCT3. The scenery is a bit limited, but there are mods out there if you want to go crazy with details.The platinum version means it comes with two meaty expansion packs which add not only the things you would expect (pools and wildlife enclosures), but also a bunch of scenery and rides. The amount of stuff in there is amazing. Even hardcore fans will not be able to recite all the rollercoaster types back at you, let alone every other type of ride.Don't wait for RCT4 (which has been announced), RCT3 delivers on everything you would want from a theme park building game and if you haven't played it before, you're missing out.

30, 2016
												I was a big fan of the second game. Loved it to hell and back. Finally, I played the third game and didn't like it. I eventually lost the second game's CD and decided to try 3: Platinum. AMAZING. I spent hour on this game and enjoy it immensely. Good controls, good rides, great challenges. No real complaints honestly. Some of the expansions are strange (the zoo especially) but no need to take part of it if you don't want. I definitely liked this game and definitely recommend. I can say honestly, there are no real negatives.

												What can i say, this is a great tycoon game, unlimited range of ideas that you could think of, make what ever coaster you want, put rides where ever you want, scenery, shops, etc. hire workers to clean up , repair rides, intertainers, police. set prices for shops and food. Fireworks, make your own shows , your own fireworks. Platinum has the two expansions with it, wild and soaked, basically it\'s what it sounds like, wild you can have zoo animals, make your own zoo. content:
, 2014
												Excellent Game.  Probably still the best tycoon game made to date.  I've had countless hours of fun with this game (not indicated by my steam activity; I played it thousands of hours before it came to steam).  All of the countless mods and custom content from the community makes this game still very attractive in a multitude of ways.  It is probably the most in depth creator type game available still.  As far as pure creativity goes, it is better than minecraft.  In terms of tycoon managment, it is easily the best of the genre.  The graphics are still on par or better than most comprable games as well.  Most current game developers could learn a lot from this game, it is still the best in the genre and almost a decade old.

												This game will never be good as it's prequels. But does that mean it is a bad game in general? Absolutely not. This game is pretty fun if you have nothing to do, and the replayability is really good. The gameplay is straight forward, like it's prequels. However, the graphics for this game suck. But as long as you're able to depict what an object is, graphics don't matter. The soundtrack is okay, but it isn't really to my liking. Good thing I can implement songs that I happen to like into the game though. Overall, this game is pretty good. Never as good as RCT 1 or RCT2, but still a good game in general.7/10

												After all this years, this game remains the unchallenged champion of theme park simulations!Its Rollercoaster editor is beyond imagination, and for the joy of the lazy ones it's also packed with an unbelievable collection of pre-designed coasters (including many perfect copies of real-world ones from famous theme parks)!The expansions (all included in the platinum version) greatly enhance the experience and grant hours of fun and a high replayability factor, whether you choose to play the scenarios or just chill out in sandbox mode with no money hassle whatsoever.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												I originally purchased this game when it first came out a in '06. At the time, I honestly didn't like it because of the change in design from the first two games. Seven years later, I wanted to play RCT2, but it wasn't available on Steam. RCT3 was on sale, so I decided to buy it. Since I haven't played either of the original two in years, it felt natural to play this one. Years later, the franchise is still awesome with excellent replayability, from campaigns to the sandbox mode.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												Do I recommend this game? ♥♥♥♥ yes I do. Unfortunately the Campaign mode is lacking majorly compared to the first two in terms of creativity, and lack of it, but is made up for easily with it's major features that improved on everything that made the first two limited to perfection. 3d camera control is nice compared to the old isometric view for making tighter twists in coasters, the graphics are more flashy which helps distinguish some things, there is a fast forward function which is helpful in tedious tasks, and the best of all Sandbox mode which you will never get bored of making different types of parks and spending hours on massive theme parks. Definitely get this game if you feel creative and imaginative, and even if you remotely remember playing even a minute of the first RollerCoaster Tycoon, grab this if you ever see it below half price. Bar the lacking campaign, it's brilliant.

er 26, 2013
												This game is a classic. I have always played this game as a kid, and finally managed to get it here on sale. As you can expect, with RollerCoaster Tycoon 3, you can build the park of your dreams. You can take on a campaign park, or take on the challenge of using sandbox to build your own park from scratch. The options are yours, and you can pick however you want it to run. This game is very family friendly, and although the graphics aren't the greatest due to it's age, it is still lovable.

content:
er 26, 2016
												Unlike RollerCoaster Tycoon 1 and 2 I don't feel that RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 stands the test of time all that well. The first two games featured sprites on a 2D plane and retains most of its charm and playability all these years later. RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 features fully 3D environments and they really show their age. The game doesn't look very good at all and while the gameplay is similar I feel its a little slower and a little more boring. Most of the people who have bought this game have played it in the past and have Nostalgia and can enjoy the game for what it is. If you've never played it before it might be a little hard to enjoy because of its age. Planet Coaster is the spiritual successor to this game (being made my the same developers) and is probably worth looking into if you're concerned about this game's age.That being said it runs perfectly fine on Windows 10 64bit and is perfectly playable. It just feels dated. With that being said I don't think I'd reccomend this game unless it was a part of your childhood or its on sale.EDIT: I've recently run into a very annoying bug where the park guests won't ride any of my rides. Its basically game breaking as I can't make any money and searching various forums turns up no real solutions.

content:
25
												I bought this game thinking I will have a great time since I read so many good reviews about it. I am not sure if my copy was possessed or if it was just the way it was meant to be. Either way, I only keep it in my library to remind myself that I need to make better choices in life. What exactly was wrong with the game? It wasn't just one thing. It was a bunch of small things that slowly angered me until I was utterly infuriated. The gameplay I experienced can only be described like this: It's like trying to stick your fork into the last pea on your plate. Whenever you think you got it the thing rolls away and you're left wondering why you've been punished. Similarly, it also leaves you feeling unsatisfied. Sure, you have the whole game. But that one last bite is still missing. That something was the soul of a theme park. I never actually felt as if I was playing a theme park simulator. It was simply too boring. I've always been a fan of tycoon games but I've never felt so enraged by a game in my life. I played through all the tutorials, read everything and made sure I understood everything. Yet the paths...the paths were acting like freaking hoodlums. Breaking whenever I thought I finally managed to build the path correctly and will be able to open the ride. But just as I tried to open the ride...bam...the freaking path trolled me again by breaking. Then I fixed the path...only for it to break in another location. I googled this and realized other people also have this issue. I tried to follow their recommendations...I really tried. I never managed to get past two rides because that path be failing every time. Everything in the game takes too much time. Going through the menu takes time, building things takes forever. (And don't think you'll be building awesome rides at first because that takes too long). Seriously, I get that there's a bit of a learning curve but after a while that just fails to excite. After all, I play games so I can instill the fake belief that I'm actually good at things, not to remind myself that I can't get my act together in a game either. I could still deal with all the time consuming parts in the game, the swarm of bugs and long tutorials, if it wasn't for the paths. I know I mentioned it before but I cannot stress enough how much the paths ruined my life. It was a when a path screamed its final hoorah and broke one time too many that I flew into a rage and uninstalled the game. Whenever I think about this game and the money I spent on it I become so horribly enraged. I'm normally a calm person but I doubt anything I can say will ever be able to capture the pure passion with which I hate this game. I truly wish I had a physical copy of this game. Why? So I can either A. rip it to shreds while I cry from frustration or B. eat it and have my body dissolve it into the poop that it was to me.

content:
er 8, 2013
												Right, so I have been a big fan of the RCT franchise because they are awesome games. A few people in the positives have written that it's great to be able to create a park that's "whatever you want". Don't get me wrong but what I want from RCT3 is the RCT franchise I know and love, except better.So the graphics: They are bad. They have dated terribly. (They are old, yes, but they have aged tragically). A few people have said the opposite but look at the pictures with people in and you'll see what I mean. This isn't necessarily an issue, but my problem was that I wanted the plain looking characters from RCT1 and 2.The interface: Again, really not that good. In RCT1/2 the interface was simple. To save you hit the floppy disk. To get rides you hit the helter skelter, to build anything you hit the crane. Well fortunately this system has been replaced with one of excessive numbers of buttons that you will never want to touch. There's no intuitive building system either.So now to the details of the game:Shops/Stalls: Now have an added feature where you can add toppings/details. Neat, huh? You can decide whether customers get cheese on the burger or not. Whether they have ice in their drink. Ice Cream in their milkshake. Now, that's all well and good except when you're setting the price of the goods it doesn't tell you how much profit per item you will make, which is a pretty important detail. No? And you're not told the costs associated with adding a topping. How useful. I suppose at least they tell you when you're undercharging.3D rollercoaster rider: Well this is a neat feature. It's not a bad idea, especially when games like theme park had the feature from the beginning. There is an unfortunate problem though, it's jolty and a bit of an anti-climax. It's a neat feature though."Parties" of Guests: Another neat feature in concept but really unnecessary. I always figure that if a tycoon game starts to make its customers more complex in a sequel then you've got problems, but for RCT I thought it might work. After all, when was the last time you went to a theme park by yourself? Unfortunately it doesn't seem to operate under general logic. If someone is going to queue up for one ride for a month then surely you'd go and get some food or walk around the scenery? No, you instead clog paths and complain, "my isn't it busy?""Three difficulty modes": Yeah... Nice try at claiming that. What that actually means is you can pass the level in three different ways. The customers aren't more difficult at a higher level, they don't need better ameneties or better roller coasters. Nope, you actually just get a more time constrained (or higher guest count/park value) with less time. Surely difficulty levels don't work that way?!?!?I am a massive (read: MASSIVE) fan of the franchise and I'd seriously suggest that if you want to give the game a go you should go and buy either roller coaster tycoon the first, or the second. The game is better. The graphics are /technically/ worse but in sum the game is better.EDIT: Anyone who is acting like I'm saying game graphics are important you will note I am saying that this gameplay is no better... and the graphics have aged badly. //This is a bad combination//.I agree that graphics aren't important, but they are a factor to be considered when buying a game.

r 15, 2016
												A year ago, I might have recommened this, but there is a good replacement for RTC3 out finally (or close to out), and it's made by the same developers. PLANET COASTER. That is the park builder you want, and it's the park builder you should buy. RCT3 was good when it came out, but it's built in with artificial performance limitations (notably save file size). In addition, it's quite unstable on newer operating systems, and has some unavoidable error messages. If you want a park builder at this budget, then one I can point you towards is Parchitect. There are others, but that has the closest feel to an RCT game (much closer to RCT2, actually).

												I love the original Rollercoaster Tycoon and was pleased to move up to 3 when given the option by a friend.   At first glance, it's pretty, nicely updated, a great step forward.  The sheer amount of stuff you could build was impressive and lord the options.  There was so many gentle rides and a plethora of restaurants to choose from, you could almost build a full park from their options alone.The water rides got a nice increase, with way more choices and little things like fireworks, scenery options, and zoo attractions where nice and should have been included way earlier than this (Like in the first game).Then I got into the game play of actually building a park and rides and discovered just how much I truly hated this version of the game.
