number of helpful: 8 of 28 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 2, 2014
												I was really excited to finally play a RCT game after nearly fourteen years, even more so after the original game disks for RCT2 wouldn't load properly on my computer. However, I became pretty confused at the menus for the game and on how to simply do things in the game.For starters, there is NO HOT KEYS programmed into the game. Another review mentions that you can rotate the camera with two keys, and then you can move around the map with the directional keys (or asdw). But that is IT. How they set it up to make the roller coasters themselves would be MUCH easier if you could use the directional keys. I lost count on how many times I had to delete tracks because I accidentally did it wrong because of the cumbersome interface.Let me say that again: it's confusing to make roller coasters in this game. Considering it's RollerCoaster Tycoon, that isn't a good thing. If your roller coaster happens to go underground, if you delete it, it doesn't undo the large hole in the ground. If you make a roller coaster too tall, it doesn't tell you it's too tall; it just says you can't build there, which causes some confusion as you try to go around it all. Messing with the ground is one of the most frustrating thing ever. Last night, I was able to make a pretty cool body of water under my roller coaster. Hours later, I decided to make a ferry in that lake to get to the other side. For some reason, I then couldn't edit the ground that I had edited earlier to make that lake; I actually could not make a deeper lake for my ferry to really go by. Then I had loads of trouble making paths that actually lined up with the buildings and rides. For at least an hour, I didn't realize that people couldn't go to the shops I made because the path "didn't line up" with it. People got stuck on pathways around there, so I had to tinker around with the path for at least thirty minutes just to get it right.The menus are just terrible here. Constantly I just pressed around until I got what I wanted. And with no hot keys, it made the process even more tedious than it should have been.So bottom line: I am playing this game, and I will be playing it more. But I am really disappointed in the controls and interface. I only played it on sandbox, where I have unlimited money; I can't imaging playing it and actually trying to make a profit. It was cool making that one roller coaster and "riding" it, and of course it's always fun to make that death roller coaster and watching people scatter and fall out of it. But I can't see me actually trying to make a successful park out of this. I'd rather try to get RCT2 working again.

number of helpful: 1 of 13 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												I had a few friends rave about RollerCoaster Tycoon and decided to give it a try when it was on sale.  I played Sim Theme Park when I was younger and had a blast with it and I hoped that RollerCoaster Tycoon would fill that void.  I was wrong.  While this game boasts some serious depth with regards to how many different types of rollercoasters, rides, and scenery you can build, those items seem irrelevant while playing (they are just for you, the AI doesn't notice it too much) and don't make up for the game's basic functionality shortcomings.The first problem I experienced was building a rollercoaster is a serious time investment.  While that is fun at first, I spent a very long time just trying to complete the circuit, which is arguably the least fun part of building a coaster.  Then I had to create the entrance and exit and found myself spending more time creating a working queue that fit with my coaster design yet still didn't attract enough riders to fill it even a quarter of the way up.My trouble really stems from the user interface for RollerCoaster Tycoon.  All the buttons are quite cryptic (just tiny icons that you have to memorize.  For example, the guest list icon has a wrench on it, which is easily confused with the staff icon, which also has a wrench on it) and I was unable to easily find hotkeys for basic tasks such as deletion, which is a two click operation each time.  The escape key, which in most games just exits the last or top-most open menu, always prompts you whether to leave your current game.  It is as if the interface designers hadn't ever played other games and made their own independent system, putting the responsibility on the user to learn how to play.The other half of my issues comes from excessive depth in construction.  As I said before, I must have spent an hour creating a path because I wasn't allowed to build it under certain segments of my coaster, while I could under other segments.  I do accept some blame for not thinking through my design, but I came from the Sim Theme Park universe, where I could have fun creating a rollercoaster and would spend more time making money from it than from building the entrances and exits.  This problem extends to shops and kiosks where if you don't toggle the "auto-levelling" feature (which should arguably be toggled on by default), even if it is up against a path, the ignorant AI can't get to the food or items.Overall, RollerCoaster Tycoon is a headache with its strange interface and picky construction rules.  I had some fun with it, but my last game was so annoying that I had to write this review.  Sim Theme Park was a great example of a fun and deep theme park game.  Yes, it was a bit cartoony and maybe even a little childish, but the interface and construction guidance allowed for some serious creativity and challenging gameplay.  Rather than frustration over how to finish your coaster and get the entrance sorted out, SimTheme Park allowed you to focus on goals of each mission.

content:
6, 2013
												Ugh. I really shouldn't be suprised. Everything in this game felt soulless and even hostile at times. I can only visualize the developers of this game as some sort of corporate zombies, tasked to emulate Roller Coaster Tycoon using New Three D Technology(tm). No thought was put into this game. nothing new. nothing original. nobody asking, "What's the best way to implement this feature that would be the most pleasing/ interesting/ convenient for the user?"       The UI was the first sign that something was horribly wrong. Almost all of the menus are on the lefthand side of the screen in a long unlabled column of vague icons which, when clicked, open up another long unlabeled column of icons. I'm sure with a little effort, I could memorize what each of the icons does, but why bother? Nothing in this game is thought out or intuitive. There's no sensible organization to the list of icons. Maybe I'll try to get around it by using hot keys? "HAHA! WHAT ARE HOTKEYS? THIS IS THE FUTURE, HERE IN THE FUTURE THERE IS ONLY ONE BUTTON AND A POINTY TRIANGLE." Really. All I can do with my keyboard is rotate the camera, Q and E. Two buttons.        Need to toggle on/off trees so I can see where I'm building my path? Lefthand column. Video controls. Toggle scenery off.... Wait... That toggles everything off? Even raised paths and rides? And they're totally invisible now? Not even a shadow to see what I'm connecting to? I just wanted to turn off trees!       But wait! there's a third key on the keyboard that woks! It's escape! No matter where you are in the game, pressing escape will bring up a box asking if you want to quit. The yes button is higlighted. The game knows. It begs to be put to rest, and forgotten into the oblivion of time. Let it's ancestors stand tall in the glory of thier nostalgic memory, but please let the world forget the bottomless misery of the last ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of the  Roller Coaster Tycoon line. Sleep now poor soul. May oblivion take you painlessly.

												They made it worse than Roller Coaster Tycoon 2. Employees quit which is a neat idea but they never tell you why so spending anytime organizing your staff feels like a gamble because they might just leave. Also the UI is somehow worse, RCT2 made sense to me with it's menus and hotkeys in this game I didn't find any useful hotkeys and the menus feel clunky trying to find certain things. This I admit would get better with time but I won't be putting time into this game. It's still Roller Coaster Tycoon just a bit worse.

content:
r 9, 2014
												5/10 Ever played a RCT game before? Me too, then I got the gamer's high and figured I'd try this old horse out again with all the shiny updates, new cover and a number "3" instead of a number "2" at the end of the title.What a waste of money.It's just as laggy and mindless as I remember, which some people like, I grant you, but I am not one of those types. This is an excellent game for a child under the age of 14 who is just breaking into a real gaming PC, but maybe FPSs or RTSs are too complicated; or the machine you're using is so out-dated that this is the only game you can play. Honestly, I see no real changes to this edition when I put it aside RCT 2. The graphics are nicer and more smooth, but all the employees, rides, options and flavour is the exact same. Sure the "story" mode has different maps and settings, but at the end of the day you're just running another crappy amusment park, advertising in the same venues, and figuring out the best way to rip off faceless droves of NPCs just enough that you gouge them without turning them away. It's a micro-manager's wet dream much in the same way that EVE is, but very much without the rewarding sense of accomplishment or space lasers.

content:
ber 23, 2016
												I spent a lot of time making my own custom water/adventure themed park, with pirates, palm, trees, and a lot of bridges over large bodies of water. The main attraction was supposed to be a sweet jet ski race course that went all the way around the park. It took a long time to make. Food, drink, souvenirs, an observation tower and a few little rides for casual enjoyment. Everything you would expect at such a place. Opening day. People begin flooding in to Adventureland Amusement. They buy the crap, they go on the bumper cars, and the trampolines, and the ferris wheel. But... but the jet ski course... remains untouched. It's open, it's perfect, nothing is wrong with the entrance. Nobody wants to go on jet skis. Nobody. The Tycoon god becomes angered, and creates an island prison for the people that complain about being hungry and thirsty when they are standing in the food court. My profits go up still, but I lose my awards little by little, and then I lose my dignity as a park manager.10/10 would spend hours on a park only to have it suck again!

er 28, 2013
												I'm amazed they never made a sequel to this. This is by far the most in depth theme park construction kit ever. It gives you the option of using easy prebuilt rides and scenery if you only feel like moving forward in the Career mode, but it also allows you to use an insane amount of custom tools and options if you feel like adding a quick flair to something or even if you want to build something special and unique from the ground up. The sandbox mode let's you experiment with or without restraint to that end.The atmosphere in this game needs to be seen and heard to be understood, it's a work of gesamtkunstwerk. Everything in this game is unified into that mode of play that only a day at a theme park seems to have, whether that's in the middle of summer without a cloud in the sky or in the middle of October when it drizzles often and every theme park brings out it's vampire costumes and spider webs. The music is especially expressive of this theme.If that's not enough, RCT 3: Platinum gives you the option to use music and pictures from your own library to use seamlessly in the park! If you just want to play a light-hearted tycoon game it's in there, if you want to spend time building a roller coaster that weaves in and out of a pirate ship while it's under attack by another pirate ship that also has a syncronized seperate roller coaster in it that uses a unique soundtrack and an accompanying fireworks display, it's also in there with tutorials. Be careful though, after a while of the former you might find yourself getting sucked into the latter.

												This is my alltime favorite rollercoaster builder. There's a tutorial to learn, sandboxmode and a campaign. Graphics are outdated but who cares. Its all about the gameplay and this game brings out the best thinkable gameplay for building a rollercoaster park combined with soaked attractions and wildlife attractions. Pros:- Freedom to build your own coasters or swimming paradise how you want it.- Graphics are from 2006 and most computers can run this game.- This Ultimate versoin contains RT3 + Soaked + Wildlife = a lot of value for a low priceCons:- The guided tutorials are semi guided and the interaction between the steps and the actions you perform are not all automated like we see in games that are more recent.- Graphics feel outdated compared to what's out on the marketI highly recommend this game if you are into themeparks and such. It's still a lot better then newer games that have better graphics but a whole different approach on gameplay and the lack of freedom to build things the way you want.

ber 22, 2014
												So yeah, Roller Coaster Tycoon. What can you even say about it really? It's a classic game series that pretty much boosted tycoon games (Other than Sim City) to more heights. So with the passage of time, Infograms we're bought out by atari and the original creator, Chris Sawyer, not working on it anymore, Atari tried to make there own RCT game; and this is how Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 came to be known as... an okay game.So I guess I have to say the pros and cons about it, soooooooooooooooooooooo...The game is now in 3D, and it works pretty well. The only real problem is trying to turn the camera up and down trying to find the perfect angle; It just resets and goes back to a semi top down perspective. The main focus of the game is that you can RIDE the RIDES, and you can kinda ride the rides, but not in the people or "peep's" point of view. Instead It's on the cart's point of view. Because the rides have feelings too you know. The gameplay is you're tipical tycoon game. But don't go building your rollercoaster of death and spooky scary skeletons, you see this game has an antagonist. The Park Inspector. He hate's everything fun and will make you throw out your anger on the keyboard. You're roller coaster is a little bit unsafe? SHUT IT DOWN! Water slide landing in the wrong pool? SHUT IT DOWN! He really makes the game less fun and you can't take him out. Also, you can't kill people in the game. I guess it makes the game more casualized since there's no worry of screwing up your coaster. Oh and one more thing to add. The zoo expansion is just Zoo Tycoon so just ask someone how Zoo Tycoon plays and that's RCT 3's Zoo expansion in a nutshell. The Water expansion just adds pools which don't really need an explanation. Same with Water Slides.So yeah, It's an okay game but not as good as the other games in the series. Really, if it was it's own game without the RCT game I think I would have liked it more, not to say It's a bad game. But with the price, I don't recommend it. Wait for a sale to get it, trust me you'll thank me later.

er 9, 2014
												A solid addition to a stellar series with a nice upgrade to 3D graphics. I would strongly suggest getting all the expansions as they add a lot of content. I find it hard to do most maps without a pool or monkey viewing venue. Being able to tweak and tune your park, the shops, and especially the rides is great. A good amount of information is presented to keep the player in control. Tons of variety in the rides, shops, and coasters. Very enjoyable!Criticisms:- It could use more feedback as to why people like a shop/ride/area or not. Generally putting stuff next to a ride will bump the excitement a few hundredths of a point. It would've been nice if there were more influential like having a bunch of creepy/scary rides feed off each other and the spooky themed scenery.- The missions have no time limit, so there's no urgency or really any posibility of failure (unless you totally suck and go deep in debt). Just run something for long enough, and you'll probably win. I usually take several hours for each scenario. If I cared more or had a reason to be more urgent, I could probably squeeze them out faster.- Building anything underground is awkward. You can make the scenery, ground, and other rides transparent or invisible, but it's still difficult to make it do what you want underground.- Even the most thrilling super ride seems to lose interest too soon. Most of the time, 99% of my patrons wander around the park. At least they get thirsty/hungry and buy my overpriced food.- Speaking of food, I've always had to jack up the price every time I place a new shop down. I don't know why they just don't start the prices near where they're supposed to be.

												I'm a huge fan of the whole 'Tycoon' genre of games, and RollerCoaster takes the cake, ever since I bought it from a charity shop a few years ago. The Platinum edition basically includes both the expansion packs, one of which was the Totally Wild (Zoo Tycoon is another one of my favourites, and this is essentially a simplified version added on) so when I saw it on sale I jumped at it.The game is very nicely balanced, you can continue building and never get bored just waiting for money to roll in (a common problem I find with these kinds of games) but only if you pace your spending. The customizations are fantastic, on the rides alone you can customize the colours, music played, queues, prices, capacity and, of course, the rides themselves, admittedly to the point of being overwhelming but that's because I'm a perfectionist who MUST RENAME EVERYTHING. Plus, even with my outdated, crabby computer it works exceptionally well - I have a park full to the brim with lights, moving rides and peeps and have only just started to get a bit of lag with 20+ smoke machines.Recommend 100%!

ry 26, 2016
												Ah, RCT3.I hadn't played RCT2 until just a few days ago, and I still have yet to get into RCT1... yet, I've played RCT3 for years, and even own a physical copy of it which refuses to install anymore. But... is it good? Rollercoaster Tycoon, if you couldn't guess, is a series of strategy games about running theme parks, managing the money your park has, and managing your guests' needs and satisfactions. It sounds so complex, but, in all honesty, it's not compared to the stressful situations in games like XCOM, Civilization, or Starcraft... but, rather...it's a more calming type of strategy game... although, maybe this is because I always screw around in the sandbox mode.But, does this mean it's perfect? No. If you're a/an elitist/purist dumbo who likes to suck the fun out of things meant not to be held but your stupidly high standards, chances are, you've already crapped on this game... but, if you're a newcomer who wants an honest answer, here you go. Having just recently played RCT2, I can see allot of differences. First off, this game is in 3D! This doesn't bother me, because the forced 2D isometric perspective of it's predicessor's leave at bit to the imagination... plus of which, there was no rotation method, which kinda sucks for an isometric game. RCT3 also allows for custom music, a new sandbox mode that doesn't take 30 minutes to set up, and and more things in the options menu. However, most of these pluses come at a cost. First off, not everybody likes the controls... personally, I think they're okay, but some people think they're a bit stiff. Secondly, the sandbox mode is actually quite limited. Part of taking 30 minutes or-so to set up a sandbox mode in the first place was adding 125+ of hundreds of stalls, coasters, and stands... and, speaking of those things, comparitively, this game has less of those than RCT2. Custom music is okay, but, you have to tick an option first, which is a nitpick more than anything else. Also, you can't kill park guests with destructive coasters anymore, which kind of defeats the purpose of that 'death park' you've had in mind.But, for all of the flaws (most of which I'm too lazy to name), I always loved the charm of RCT3. I love the way birds instantly lose all their feathers when you click on them, I love the way guests get all scared when you spy on them. Also, I love having little Johnny spend an entire year riding 'Get In Line: The Ride', then commenting on how cool it was (true story, btw).

er 5, 2015
												RCT 3 is a major step forward in the RCT franchise and adds so much more to the game that it would be very hard to be bored with this game. Being able to now ride the rides was a much needed necessity and added so much depth to the game itself. The larger park size was enough to create any playground of fun without running out of room for expansion. Bringing forward most of the features that were in the previous title, it still feels very much like and has the touch of a RCT game.Now with that said, it does have some drawbacks. The cartoonish peeps are just not as vibrant as the little peeps in RCT2. The peep interaction in RCT 2 feels more fun and vibrating. Building roller coasters in RCT 2 felt more fun and puzzling. That's not to say that RCT 3 coasters were dull, because they weren't. they just lacked the circus fun that RCT 2 had. Creating buildings in RCT 3 had more options and became easier and felt more real. Adding billboards added to the realism of real life parks and made a major difference in aesthetic pleasure. Being able to create your own fireworks show with the Mixmaster was a major step forward and added an extra layer to building a awesome park and helped bring the park alive, something that RCT 2, at times, lacked.The water and animal expansion packs helped bring the game to full circle, allowing versatility in building any kind of theme park that you could imagine. Being able to create pools was another needed must have that the game deserved and gave the ability to choose what kind of Theme Park you wanted to create from an animal park to just a water park to a coaster haven. RCT 3 is a complete game with three games wrapped into one.  There is no question that Frontier Developments brought the series to a new level which gave you the option to never get bored with game. Hours on end, there is no question that RCT 3 is a winner is all aspects and changed the series forever upping the ante on how future versions would be crafted and created. 5 stars out of 5 stars. Highly recommended for die-hard fans of the series.

(Also you may compare it with the "MOTHERLOAD" code in Sims, which gives you a LOT of money)The Campaign mode, is another type of challenge where you need build certain building and stand up to some standarts whileas keeping inside a budget.There are also more different modes that help you understand more of the game, or just build crazy machines and laser shows for future needs.I really recomend it, especially if you are a fan of making people sick on ride, by building a rollercoaster drop from 50 meters!

												Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 Platinum works perfectly under Windows 10.Under Windows 7 the game locks up at 67% when trying to enter any game mode.The windows site maintains the game is compatible with windows 7, but there are literally thousands of posts from users having the same problem as myself.  Compatibility mode does not work.  There are no working fixes or patches.The STEAM version of this game however works perfectly under Windows 10.There are three modes to play, Tutorial, Scenario/challenge and Sandbox.The game sounds and plays just like it did when it came out, but new resolutions have been added to accommodate HD wide screen monitors.It is so good to have an old favourite back up and running under Windows 10!  Not sure if I need to thank Microsoft or Atari for this ... but great job guys you have made at least one person really happy!!!11/10 will remove a piece of track from the rollercoaster again :)

												Have you ever dreamed of owning a theme park? Me neither. Or so I thought, browsing through my father's games as a kid.I was wrong. Boy, I was wrong.This game has the three Cs of a good sandbox - Challenge, Content, and Creativity. Design your own parks or play Scenarios and help their premade parks rise to the top. Build coasters, flat rides, shops, paths, terrain, zoos, pools, and a surprisingly huge amount of other theme park essentials. Hire staff, manage prices, and attract guests to your park.Alternatively, you can build rides that launch carts into crowds of people, or unleash wild predators into your park to watch as your patrons run around screaming for their lives.The developer of this game, Frontier, created a masterpiece worthy of me buying again on Steam solely for the convenience of having it digitally.This is one of the best games ever made, hands down.

ry 26, 2016
												Ah, RCT3.I hadn't played RCT2 until just a few days ago, and I still have yet to get into RCT1... yet, I've played RCT3 for years, and even own a physical copy of it which refuses to install anymore. But... is it good? Rollercoaster Tycoon, if you couldn't guess, is a series of strategy games about running theme parks, managing the money your park has, and managing your guests' needs and satisfactions. It sounds so complex, but, in all honesty, it's not compared to the stressful situations in games like XCOM, Civilization, or Starcraft... but, rather...it's a more calming type of strategy game... although, maybe this is because I always screw around in the sandbox mode.But, does this mean it's perfect? No. If you're a/an elitist/purist dumbo who likes to suck the fun out of things meant not to be held but your stupidly high standards, chances are, you've already crapped on this game... but, if you're a newcomer who wants an honest answer, here you go. Having just recently played RCT2, I can see allot of differences. First off, this game is in 3D! This doesn't bother me, because the forced 2D isometric perspective of it's predicessor's leave at bit to the imagination... plus of which, there was no rotation method, which kinda sucks for an isometric game. RCT3 also allows for custom music, a new sandbox mode that doesn't take 30 minutes to set up, and and more things in the options menu. However, most of these pluses come at a cost. First off, not everybody likes the controls... personally, I think they're okay, but some people think they're a bit stiff. Secondly, the sandbox mode is actually quite limited. Part of taking 30 minutes or-so to set up a sandbox mode in the first place was adding 125+ of hundreds of stalls, coasters, and stands... and, speaking of those things, comparitively, this game has less of those than RCT2. Custom music is okay, but, you have to tick an option first, which is a nitpick more than anything else. Also, you can't kill park guests with destructive coasters anymore, which kind of defeats the purpose of that 'death park' you've had in mind.But, for all of the flaws (most of which I'm too lazy to name), I always loved the charm of RCT3. I love the way birds instantly lose all their feathers when you click on them, I love the way guests get all scared when you spy on them. Also, I love having little Johnny spend an entire year riding 'Get In Line: The Ride', then commenting on how cool it was (true story, btw).

ber 5, 2013
												For those who relish in nostalgia, or for those just coming across it, Roller Coaster Tycoon is the quintessential tycoon game. The third installment in the series far surpasses the second, but is almost a different breed than the first. Not to argue that it isn't an improvement, simply that the two games seem to offer quite a unique playing style while both being part of the same franchise. The ability to ride coasters in a first-person view, is a welcome addition in this version of the game. The fireworks mixmaster disply is decent enough, however there seems to be some lacking instructional material that covers the laser light show side of the same rig. Nevertheless, Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 is a very solid purchase and a classic addition to any game library. Four stars.

ry 23, 2014
												I remember playing the first Rollercoaster Tycoon as a kid with my sister. Good old nostalgia tempted me into buying this when it was on sale one day, and I've never regretted the decision. RollerCoaster Tycoon is a simple game with a simple objective: you build a theme park. While you can play the campaign and aim for creating a profitable park and meet certain objectives, you can also opt to play the sandbox mode instead. Aside from the sandbox mode, there is also the scenario builder. You can create your own perameters for how you want to play the game. Do you want certain weather or infinite money? Go for it. RollerCoaster Tycoon might be on the older side, but it is certainly a game that can be enjoyed by any age.

ry 9, 2014
												RCT3 is potentially one of my favorite games. I've been a roller coaster lover since I was a kid, so maybe it's that.The game has multiple scenarios you can play through, or mess around in a sandbox or custom scenario. There is no store where you can buy things with real money, everything is in the game. Another plus is this is platinum edition, so you get access to the Wild expandsion pack and the Soaked expansion pack, both adding quite a few things to the game.Of course, you can construct any roller coaster you would like for your park, or select a premade one. You can also save your coasters to use in a different game, or perhaps even a RCT4.The graphics are fairly well, being a decade old game, except the people in the game have blocky faces, though this can be quite funny.The finance system is extremely designed. You have to hire janitors and mechanics, and you have to pay them a salary. Shops and rollercoasters cost money to run, so you need to make sure that the amount of money they are pulling in from the people outweighs the running cost, otherwise you will go into debt. You can also run ad campains to advertise your park and have people come visit. These include coupons for specific rides, a get in free coupon, or just a plain advertisement. Of course, these cost money, just like they would in real life, so you can't spend all your savings on ad campains.Overall an extremely fun game which has a good finance system and if you love roller coasters, you will love this game to death.9.5/10did i mention you can ride your coasters?

er 7, 2014
												Rollercoaster Tycoon...a huge part of my childhood. I love these games. There's something about slowly building up your park from a cute little amusement park to a giant attention-grabbing attraction. The game progresses at the pace you play it, so you can race to become the most well-known park in the area, or you can slowly but surely increase your park's size until you're happy with it. One of the main parts of the RCT games is the ability to design your own roller coasters. Not a lot has changed with that mechanic since the first game, but there have been improvements. One of the most memorable improvements to the games is that now, in this game, you can ride the coasters you build. This adds the extremely satisfying ability to virtually test every coaster you make, which makes crafting your own coasters even more rewarding. This game also allows you to customize some of the peeps (customers) that visit your park. This is actually a pretty cool addition to the series, as it adds that nice little feeling you get when you recognize a familiar peep walking around in your park. All in all, if you're not into managing simulation games, even when they're simplified, you might want to skip over this game. On the other hand, if you're looking for a fun game that will eat up your hours like a toddler eats cotton candy, or even want to try a new managing sim, then I highly recommend this title.

												A lot of people tend to hate this version of RCT simply because RCT2 exists and the move to 3D maybe hurt the series a bit. However, most of the functionality of RCT1+2 still exist in this, but with some improvements to quite a few aspects (such as proper pathing for park guests and allowing construction while the rest of the park is paused).The scenarios in 3 are pretty simple, with most second objectives being to pay off the loan. While the scenarios aren't really challenging most of the time, a lot of them are still fun. If you are the kind that just likes to build a theme park, Sandbox Mode exists for you to toy around with whatever designs you want.The only thing that really suffers is terrain modifying, since modifying smooth hills can be a major pain to construct anything on top of. However, everything else is pretty solid, and Platinum adds in a ton of content.Certainly worth picking up.

												The first game i've ever pre-ordered, I played the crap out of this game when it first came out back in 2004. Now nearly 10 years later, I still come back to this game. RCT2 was my first intoduction into the world of RCT, and I remember how blown away I was when RCT3 was announced with 3d graphics. 10 year old me was really wowed by the ability to ride your rides. Over the next few years after it's initial release, it added so much awesome content with the ability to build water parks as well as create your own safari. I had fun equally playing career mode taking on many challenges, then playing sandbox mode with an unlimited budget, allowing myself to build what I wanted to build. Also, if you get this game, don't forget to check out the loads of custom content put out by the awesome RCT community.

												I never played RollerCoaster Tycoon before, so for me the nostalgia part doesn't quite exists.What I can tell about this game is that it is SUPER fun... If you are a begginer like me you should play at some of the tutorials, they will teach you how to control your Amusement park, while showing you the cool features of the game.The Sandbox mode, is a good place to practice your RollerCoaster building skills as well as Ground Shaping skills. (Also you may compare it with the "MOTHERLOAD" code in Sims, which gives you a LOT of money)The Campaign mode, is another type of challenge where you need build certain building and stand up to some standarts whileas keeping inside a budget.There are also more different modes that help you understand more of the game, or just build crazy machines and laser shows for future needs.I really recomend it, especially if you are a fan of making people sick on ride, by building a rollercoaster drop from 50 meters!

er 5, 2015
												RCT 3 is a major step forward in the RCT franchise and adds so much more to the game that it would be very hard to be bored with this game. Being able to now ride the rides was a much needed necessity and added so much depth to the game itself. The larger park size was enough to create any playground of fun without running out of room for expansion. Bringing forward most of the features that were in the previous title, it still feels very much like and has the touch of a RCT game.Now with that said, it does have some drawbacks. The cartoonish peeps are just not as vibrant as the little peeps in RCT2. The peep interaction in RCT 2 feels more fun and vibrating. Building roller coasters in RCT 2 felt more fun and puzzling. That's not to say that RCT 3 coasters were dull, because they weren't. they just lacked the circus fun that RCT 2 had. Creating buildings in RCT 3 had more options and became easier and felt more real. Adding billboards added to the realism of real life parks and made a major difference in aesthetic pleasure. Being able to create your own fireworks show with the Mixmaster was a major step forward and added an extra layer to building a awesome park and helped bring the park alive, something that RCT 2, at times, lacked.The water and animal expansion packs helped bring the game to full circle, allowing versatility in building any kind of theme park that you could imagine. Being able to create pools was another needed must have that the game deserved and gave the ability to choose what kind of Theme Park you wanted to create from an animal park to just a water park to a coaster haven. RCT 3 is a complete game with three games wrapped into one.  There is no question that Frontier Developments brought the series to a new level which gave you the option to never get bored with game. Hours on end, there is no question that RCT 3 is a winner is all aspects and changed the series forever upping the ante on how future versions would be crafted and created. 5 stars out of 5 stars. Highly recommended for die-hard fans of the series.

												RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is a game where you are put into a position of building and managing an amusement park. The amusement park you create can have attractions ranging from concession stands to animal enclosures and pool complexes (and of course, you can build rollercoasters), but the best thing to do is trap your guests (and maybe staff) in a small enclosed area and release large carnivorous animals into the pack of people. Unfortunately, in this installment, you cannot kill your guests or staff, so while I do recommend this game, it might be more worth your while to purchase one of the previous games depending on the mechanics you are interested in.

												A lot of people tend to hate this version of RCT simply because RCT2 exists and the move to 3D maybe hurt the series a bit. However, most of the functionality of RCT1+2 still exist in this, but with some improvements to quite a few aspects (such as proper pathing for park guests and allowing construction while the rest of the park is paused).The scenarios in 3 are pretty simple, with most second objectives being to pay off the loan. While the scenarios aren't really challenging most of the time, a lot of them are still fun. If you are the kind that just likes to build a theme park, Sandbox Mode exists for you to toy around with whatever designs you want.The only thing that really suffers is terrain modifying, since modifying smooth hills can be a major pain to construct anything on top of. However, everything else is pretty solid, and Platinum adds in a ton of content.Certainly worth picking up.

er 2, 2014
												A great sandbox game. Better (In my humble opinion) than RCT 1 and 2. The game by itself is great, and allows you to be as creative as you want, or rush to that milestone as quickly as possible. If you are like me, and find good sandbox games to be a giant time sucking destroyer of relationships/ruiner of financial stability, then your in luck! There is a mode where you can progress to a certain point, and your finished! You can step back, and know your job is done. And then take a 20min nap and get back to your real job.... Anyways-Mods. Thats right, mods.This game REALLY shines if you install mods. Allowing you to create replicas of Disneyland, Cedar point, or a moon base turned amusment park. You can (with some basic 3D modelling knowledge) create your own objects to be put in, or simply download off of the many 'warehouse' custom-scenery websites. If you are like me, you will spend more time searching the web (deeply) for mods then actually playing the game. You will run out of room on your harddrive, and your GPU's VRAM will scream in agony... All optional though. THIS TIME I'll be only getting a few basics and just playing the.... Wait... King's Island all scenery expansion, only 1TB?... *downloads*

er 2, 2014
 RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum REVIEW Hi everyone, welcome to this review. In this review I will cover every single part of the review, so it'll probably be a lengthy one. I have played it much longer but that wasn't the Platinum-edition and not on the Steam-platform. So if it doesn't look like I've played long, it's because of that. Graphics However the graphics aren't that important, it is good to cover these first to get it out of the way.Don't expect much from the graphics. It is a game from 2004 and however there are games from that year that looked much better, this looks fine too. The lights look a bit weird sometimes, so that could've had some improvements. There are some cool textures for the Peeps, but it still feels incomplete with only a couple of hairstyles, two different T-shirts and a pair of jeans. Animations look fine. The best thing I like is the visuals of the CoasterCam. These look really cool.With everything combined I give the graphics a  7.5/10 . Gameplay I think the gameplay is the most important part of the game. It is after all a simulation game.The gameplay is great. The core gameplay is of course building rollercoasters and make sure people don't die when entering them. And that works great. It is simple, but effective. You should buy the expansion packs with it, because they add a lot more features to it. Wild! gives you the opportunity to make your own safaripark, and Soaked! gives you some very cool pools and waterslides. That is why you should buy the Platinum-edition. One of the things I like to do the most, is make a very cool Lion Show, with my own shows. Yes, you can make your own shows by mixing some awesome tricks. You can do that as well with Fireworks and Dolphin Shows.The gameplay is awesome.  9/10  Other stuff There is a lot of other things to do, besides the campaign and sandbox. In the "Tools" section, you can make your own families, rollercoasters, shows and scenarios. You should really try this.It is not the most fun thing to do, but you can really use it in your parks, without actually creating them in your parks.  8/10  Final answer Is this game good? Yes, it is.Should you buy it? Yes, you should.The game is really awesome. Here's a quick summary: Graphics: 7.5/10 Gameplay: 9/10 Other stuff: 8/10 So with everything combined, this game gets a: 8.5/10  Thanks for reading this review!

												RCT3, although a bit buggy, is a great park simulator game. It is very easy to pick up (and has tutorials for newcomers), and the Sandbox mode allows you to create large, expansive parks.Positives:-3D Graphics are great-Custom Music-Fun scenarios-Unlimited creation (I created an underground park, indoor park, and have seen creations such as cruise ships and cities)-Coaster cam is funNegatives:-A bit buggy-Runs slow on large parks (runs a lot better on Steam than from disk)-Limited scenery options-Unrealistic supports/scenery (download a scenery set of supports for more realism)-Lack of gentle ridesAlso note that I have many more than 12 hours on this game, as I originally purchased this game on release day, as well as its expansions, before purchasing it on Steam years later.

												I'm so glad I bought this game! This game lets you create your very own theme park and rides to your heart's content. I love being able to "ride" the rides and see what attractions my guests like and not like. It might seem a little tedious and boring starting out but once you get used to it, it's very fun! And with two expansion packs included, the fun just gets better. I like including animal exhibits and building water rides for my pool section. Building roller coasters are the best, I usually make mine insane but I do make gentle rides for those who can't take the speed and loops! I would recommend this game to everyone :)

If you do like the ability to look around in 3D maybe you'll like this better, but I have found myself liking RCT2 better than 3 at times because in 3 the 3D gets complicated for me, vs the isometric view (which to be fair you can enable in RCT3) that allows you to not have to worry about camera angles too much. But on the contrary navigating eveything in 3D is way cool too. I don't know, this is a hard review for me to write, and I can't really say much useful except that if you like any RCT you should like this one too, they're all complimentary to each other. And RCT the original just has this awesome nostalgia with the low res graphics and music that's unforgettable. Just get them all!

												This is the third in the RollerCoaster Tycoon series, and it's actually one of my favorites. It takes the scenario progression from the first game, the stacking scenery from the second one, wraps it in a nice, though somewhat buggy, 3D package... And throws in the ability to ride the rides in first person.RollerCoaster Tycoon is all about building and managing your own theme park. Everything from how much the fries in the back of the park cost, to how big of a water park you want, to fully customizable rides. You can build yourself any size coaster, color it the way you want, and theme it accordingly. If you like any management-style games, and you like amusement parks, this is the game for you. Have fun.

er 26, 2015
												I recently re-purchased this game on Steam. I own a disk version, but it's so cheap right now I figured it was worth purchasing, if only for the OSX version.RCT3 is the third installment of a well-loved and, from my perspective, extremely important franchise. The first two games were landmarks of video gaming, and almost certainly the best of the "Tycoon" series. They were also programmer (in assembly) by one guy, Chris Sawyer. As if that wasn't insane enough, Sawyer also did all the art assets and music. The first two games are unique in that regard, and also unique in the place they hold in many gamers' hearts.On a more personal level, RCT2 was the first game I ever played on a personal computer. I have a lot of childhood memories behind that game.This, however, is supposed to be a review of RCT3, not RCT2. Well, fear not: RCT3 is indeed quite a good game. Part of me wants to try and compare it with the others in the franchise, but I think that's a rather pointless endeavor. There's no way I can be objective about it, for one, and the games came out at very different times. I definitely didn't play RCT3 as much as I played RCT2, but that doesn't make it a worse game. In fact, I think I enjoyed creating water parks in this game more than I enjoyed anything in RCT2, although that might be a result of my love of water parks more than any merit of the gameplay itself.The game is not without problems. Ending waterslides feels weird, and the camera is a bit clunky at times. Some of the coaster types aren't really fun to build, and editing coasters can be a bit awkward if they go underground. Still, the game is pretty fun.Overall, this is well worth the sale price. If you're interested in building coasters at all, you'll get a solid eight hours out of this game, at a minimium. If you love the franchise, like I do, you'll probably get much more than that.

ber 22, 2014
												So yeah, Roller Coaster Tycoon. What can you even say about it really? It's a classic game series that pretty much boosted tycoon games (Other than Sim City) to more heights. So with the passage of time, Infograms we're bought out by atari and the original creator, Chris Sawyer, not working on it anymore, Atari tried to make there own RCT game; and this is how Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 came to be known as... an okay game.So I guess I have to say the pros and cons about it, soooooooooooooooooooooo...The game is now in 3D, and it works pretty well. The only real problem is trying to turn the camera up and down trying to find the perfect angle; It just resets and goes back to a semi top down perspective. The main focus of the game is that you can RIDE the RIDES, and you can kinda ride the rides, but not in the people or "peep's" point of view. Instead It's on the cart's point of view. Because the rides have feelings too you know. The gameplay is you're tipical tycoon game. But don't go building your rollercoaster of death and spooky scary skeletons, you see this game has an antagonist. The Park Inspector. He hate's everything fun and will make you throw out your anger on the keyboard. You're roller coaster is a little bit unsafe? SHUT IT DOWN! Water slide landing in the wrong pool? SHUT IT DOWN! He really makes the game less fun and you can't take him out. Also, you can't kill people in the game. I guess it makes the game more casualized since there's no worry of screwing up your coaster. Oh and one more thing to add. The zoo expansion is just Zoo Tycoon so just ask someone how Zoo Tycoon plays and that's RCT 3's Zoo expansion in a nutshell. The Water expansion just adds pools which don't really need an explanation. Same with Water Slides.So yeah, It's an okay game but not as good as the other games in the series. Really, if it was it's own game without the RCT game I think I would have liked it more, not to say It's a bad game. But with the price, I don't recommend it. Wait for a sale to get it, trust me you'll thank me later.

3, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the hours in this game on Steam. I have spent many of hours on this game ever since 2008 in a box retail version.How do I sum this game up?Well, this game is all about making Roller Coasters, right? It's in the title. Well, it is that, but it's way more than building roller coasters. You mainly build theme parks for people to enjoy in. Mostly, building coasters, rides, food stalls, and basically maintaining a theme park.To start out, I'd recommend you play in Sandbox mode so you can fool around with the editor. You have unlimited money and you start out on a superflat world with the biggest park size. There, you can build your park. Add roller coasters, make carousells, make other flat rides, as well as making food and drink stalls, with other things. The Platinum version of the game adds in the 2 other expansion packs: Soaked! and Wild!. Soaked adds in pools, more coasters, the ability to build underground, and more stuffs. Wild adds in the ability to make enclosures to house animals of many kinds, coasters, rides, and more. With these things all togeather, you can make a Mega Park/WaterPark/Zoo.But if you are willing for a challange, try out the career mode, where you are given a scenario, and you have to complete the objectives before you can move on. Most of the scenario parks are given to you in the beginning, but to unlock the later ones, you have to reach a certain level in each park. It's tricky. Sadly, you won't gain anything for this except pre-made roller coaster designs, but for people wanting a challenge, go for it. There's different parks for each expansion pack, so you can play all the levels.This game was also important to me because this was my 1st real PC game in 2008, and I made 70+ parks on my crappy old Vista desktop. Too many hours to count on this game, and now I got it on Steam.You thought it stopped with the game? Nope, because out there on the wild internet you can find custom content. Custom coasters, flat rides, and most importantly, custom scenery. These mods make your game look better than with the stock scenery. Mods include coaster supports, lights, catwalks, fences, and much more. Also, they made an invisible ride entrance and exit, so you arn't stuck with the stupid stock ones. There's a wealth of mods out there, and lots of tutorials on how to install them. I will also be providing a link to a Steam guide to all of the mods I use, so you can see the stuff I like.All in all, RCT3 is one of the greatest games out there. If you are new to the RCT series, this game is the easiest to get into, then you can discover the first 2 games. There's also a 4th game in the process of being made, called World. Anything that this game didn't have will be added in World, and that comes to the bad things about this game.First, like the first 2 games, your whole park is like a giant grid system. Each grid block at a certain height will be taken up when you place something there. Although this is great for beginners, it's not that great for people that want to be creative. You just want to move this wall 2 inches to connect to the other wall, but you can't. Second, probably due to the game engine being from 2004, if you zoom away from an object, they have the chance of dissapearing. And also compared to todays standards, everything looks a bit blocky. Depending on your computer likes and dislikes, this game might not even work! If you get this game, you have to be willing to mess with the settings to get the most out of it for your machine.To end this rambling, this game is amazing. Just spend $20 and get it. I got about $35 in RCT3 stuff alone, with getting the base game and expansion packs alone, and then getting this combo copy on Steam. That shows you how much I like this game.9/10 You can charge people to go to the bathroom!

												RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is a game where you are put into a position of building and managing an amusement park. The amusement park you create can have attractions ranging from concession stands to animal enclosures and pool complexes (and of course, you can build rollercoasters), but the best thing to do is trap your guests (and maybe staff) in a small enclosed area and release large carnivorous animals into the pack of people. Unfortunately, in this installment, you cannot kill your guests or staff, so while I do recommend this game, it might be more worth your while to purchase one of the previous games depending on the mechanics you are interested in.

And if you want to enjoy the rollarcoaster or any other ride in the game for that matter, you can jump into first person and go up and down and around and all the rest on the rides. Yea yea graphics aren't the bomb. The people are a little block-ish. But the game is a bit old (no kidding) and the pros completely stomp the cons. If you enjoy creative games with much freedom. Get this game.

												Roller Coaster Tycoon is an old game series, now being revived by Planet Coaster, where you build a Theme Park and make your peeps (guests) happy. You can choose from a few game modes, my favorite, of course, is sandbox, where you have unlimited money and can build to your heart's content in a humongous clear field. The other gamemodes include the campaign mode (limited money) and scenarios to test your theme park skills and learn new concepts of the game. You can build huge roller coasters and theme your park like crazy. You can also include carnival rides.You can also be evil, which is incredibly fun, and build roller coasters that lead to nowhere, and watch your guests explode and crash into walls, but it is child friendly, so everyone survives, so don't worry about that.Though this game is old, it is still one of my most favorite games ever. Do yourself a favor and at least try it, and I'll guaranty you'll have at least a little fun.

												This game is absolutely fanstastic and I have failed time after time to find anything dislikeable about it whatsoever. The graphics are very old but still look fantastic, the building tools feel solid and are easy to use (though building on terrain can be annoying) and the gameplay and feel is amazing... This game is just sooo good. This is by far my favorite Tycoon game ever and I doubt any Tycoon game will come close to this or any of the other games in the series, which are also amazing and are classics. This game is easy to learn and once you do, the creativity just flows. The possibilities are endless. This game also runs extremely well on any pc.If you are into game such as Call Of Duty or any fps or MOBA games, this probably is not the game for you because it takes a very large amount of your time, but if you have inspiration and creativity and wish to see your dream park come together, this is for you.  I highly recomend all three games in the series as they are all classics and they are all absolutely fantastic.

												After the upgrade to Windows 10 (with the SecuROM which is attached to the CD version of this game) I couldn't install the CD version anymore as an error kept popping up after 68% completed. That's where I decided to buy this game again on my AMD FX(tm)-8350 Eight-Core Processor (4.50 GHz). At first it seemed to work. It loaded up my old parks and CSO, CFR and CTRs as I expected. But after several times saving a park and loading it up (which first always worked on my old version of RCT3) it keeps crashing after loading a park up. I tried to find the source for it, changed the graphics removed the RCT3.fc in Documents/RCT3/Parks and Structures file as this is always a major problem when copying an old folder and replacing the new one (has to do with the administrator rights) and tried to change the resolution (I'm using a widescreen so I'm using the option 1280 x 960 x 32) but that doesn't fix the source of the crash. I'm desperate regarding this, and felt the need to share this for you as (eventual) buyer using Windows 10. Many like me are maintaining this problem, but the strange thing is that some don't at all! Maybe it has to do with the fact I'm using custom theming and custom rides, and somewhere a corrupt file got between my data but then again the map exactly as I have now always used to work on my old pc (which was a Windows XP and even on Windows 8.1 it works fine). So if you want to buy this even though you know the consequences which may come with this, I give you the advice to ALWAYS KEEP YOUR GAME UPDATED when using custom theming! It may help you in solving a (future) crash you may maintain like me.Other than my personal failures I'm maintaining, I highly recommend this game if you like sandbox modes and theme parks (or fairgrounds, as you can build your own fairground with the right theming). The game also have a career option of you managing an already existing theme park. It comes with a lot of features, and I promise you it won't let you down! It have a firework, laser and watershow editor option of creating your own shows! You can hire and fire employees. In short: all what comes with managing a theme park! But with that and with the malfunction I shared above, I warn users using a high-tech computer system as this game is dating from 2005 (2004 in the Northern America). The game is not updated as there is already a new version of Rollercoaster Tycoon on the market: Rollercoaster Tycoon World. So buying this with a high-tech PC is a gamble. As I said, some are lucky and some (like me) are not unfortunately. You got it all in the hand of how expansive you want the game to be.

												RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 is a game where you are put into a position of building and managing an amusement park. The amusement park you create can have attractions ranging from concession stands to animal enclosures and pool complexes (and of course, you can build rollercoasters), but the best thing to do is trap your guests (and maybe staff) in a small enclosed area and release large carnivorous animals into the pack of people. Unfortunately, in this installment, you cannot kill your guests or staff, so while I do recommend this game, it might be more worth your while to purchase one of the previous games depending on the mechanics you are interested in.

er 27, 2016
												Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 was the one of the first PC games that got me into gaming. Its detailed mechanics make the game really memorable and replayble to where you never really want to stop playing. The management options are so extremely intricate that you can even adjust the amount of condiments go on the burgers. Roller coaster buliding is enjoyable - not tedious or repetitve - while also being challenging in where you have to adjust the twists and turns just right in order to achieve a certain nausea or excitement rating. Even more content is in the game for the player to build and enjoy, but I won't spoil that fun: you'll have to play the game yourself to see what else there is to enjoy ;) But, there is a plethora of integrated cheats in the game like naming a park guest "James Hunt" to spawn a dune buggy that you can not-so-carefully drive and run over the park guests with. You can find the rest of the cheats online with a simple search; they make the game a whole lot more enjoyable.I nominated this game for The "Test Of Time" Award because of the reasons above and would also nominate it for The "Just 5 More Minutes" Award if I could. I gave that to Planet Coaster because it's this game but with better graphics, more to build, more detail, more everything, and it's new and being updated with even more amazing content by a company that actually cares about the product they're creating and giving to thier audience. Too bad there are no cheats... I really want to run over park guests in 4K...

												Have you ever dreamed of owning a theme park? Me neither. Or so I thought, browsing through my father's games as a kid.I was wrong. Boy, I was wrong.This game has the three Cs of a good sandbox - Challenge, Content, and Creativity. Design your own parks or play Scenarios and help their premade parks rise to the top. Build coasters, flat rides, shops, paths, terrain, zoos, pools, and a surprisingly huge amount of other theme park essentials. Hire staff, manage prices, and attract guests to your park.Alternatively, you can build rides that launch carts into crowds of people, or unleash wild predators into your park to watch as your patrons run around screaming for their lives.The developer of this game, Frontier, created a masterpiece worthy of me buying again on Steam solely for the convenience of having it digitally.This is one of the best games ever made, hands down.

												I love this game. RollerCoaster Tycoon 3: Platinum adds the great idea of riding your rides after building them. It brings the world of RCT into 3D. The rides are great and are really fun to build. The AI of the people isn't great and there isn't a lot of scenery choices, but the rides make up for it. They improved the sandbox by making it its own thing instead of having to make a new custom scenario just for it. There are multiple carrer choices that each have one objective but after you complete the first, it makes it tougher by making you expand your goal even more. If you have trouble understanding how to play the game, there is a tutorial mode that will help you on your way to becoming the best rollercoaster park designer that you can be. I would fully recommend this game to anyone who has the time and patiece to make your park look great and making your rollercoasters amazing. This is one of my favorite games, which may seem sad, but it is that good. If you have the money to buy this game, get it right away.

												I like rollercoasters... period. I also like management games. This has both. It is fun and can get very hard later into the game. This is the (in my opinion) the last good Roller Coaster Tycoon game. It has a normal level system and also has a sandbox mode where you can really flex your creativity. Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 is one of those games where you decide to play for a couple minutes, then before you know it multiple hours have passed. It is just a timeless classic to me.

er 23, 2016
												Roller Coaster Tycoon is an old game series, now being revived by Planet Coaster, where you build a Theme Park and make your peeps (guests) happy. You can choose from a few game modes, my favorite, of course, is sandbox, where you have unlimited money and can build to your heart's content in a humongous clear field. The other gamemodes include the campaign mode (limited money) and scenarios to test your theme park skills and learn new concepts of the game. You can build huge roller coasters and theme your park like crazy. You can also include carnival rides.You can also be evil, which is incredibly fun, and build roller coasters that lead to nowhere, and watch your guests explode and crash into walls, but it is child friendly, so everyone survives, so don't worry about that.Though this game is old, it is still one of my most favorite games ever. Do yourself a favor and at least try it, and I'll guaranty you'll have at least a little fun.

ry 12
												As with the 2 predecessors, if you didn't play this game as a kid, you didn't have a childhood. Unlike the predecessors though, this game is fully 3D and lets you ride the rides, and has an actual sandbox mode, and therefore justifies the $20 price tag. Still is a modest price to pay for a game of this time. If you're cheap like I am, you can wait for the summer or winter sale, where this will get marked down significantly.
